         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3">

      <p>
       <b>
        Lithuania
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">
            ˌ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">
            ɪ
           </span>
           <span title="/θj/: 'th' in 'enthuse'">
            θj
           </span>
           <span title="/u/: 'u' in 'influence'">
            u
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">
            eɪ
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Lithuania.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/En-us-Lithuania.ogg" title="En-us-Lithuania.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="lt">
         Lietuva
        </span>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Lithuanian" title="Help:IPA/Lithuanian">
         [lʲɪɛtʊˈvɐ]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Lithuania
       </b>
       (Lithuanian:
       <i>
        <span lang="lt">
         Lietuvos Respublika
        </span>
       </i>
       ), is a country in the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_region" title="Baltic region">
        Baltic region
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        northern
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">
        eastern Europe
       </a>
       . One of the three
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic states
       </a>
       , it is situated along the southeastern shore of the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">
        Baltic Sea
       </a>
       , to the east of
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       . It is bordered by
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       to the north,
       <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">
        Belarus
       </a>
       to the east and south,
       <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
        Poland
       </a>
       to the south, and
       <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">
        Kaliningrad Oblast
       </a>
       (a
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russian
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">
        exclave
       </a>
       ) to the southwest. Lithuania has an estimated population of 2.8 million people as of 2017
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , and its capital and largest city is
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">
        Lithuanians
       </a>
       are a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_people" title="Baltic people">
        Baltic people
       </a>
       . The official language,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       , along with
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">
        Latvian
       </a>
       , is one of only two living languages in the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">
        Baltic branch
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
        Indo-European
       </a>
       language family.
      </p>
      <p>
       For centuries, the southeastern shores of the Baltic Sea were inhabited by various
       <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">
        Baltic tribes
       </a>
       . In the 1230s, the Lithuanian lands were united by
       <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">
        Mindaugas
       </a>
       , the King of Lithuania, and the first unified Lithuanian state, the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lithuania" title="Kingdom of Lithuania">
        Kingdom of Lithuania
       </a>
       , was created on 6 July 1253. During the 14th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">
        Grand Duchy of Lithuania
       </a>
       was the largest country in Europe; present-day Lithuania, Belarus, Ukraine, and parts of Poland and Russia were the territories of the Grand Duchy. With the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lublin_Union" title="Lublin Union">
        Lublin Union
       </a>
       of 1569, Lithuania and Poland formed a voluntary two-state union, the
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
       </a>
       . The Commonwealth lasted more than two centuries, until neighboring countries
       <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">
        systematically dismantled
       </a>
       it from 1772 to 1795, with the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       annexing most of Lithuania's territory.
      </p>
      <p>
       As
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       neared its end, Lithuania's
       <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">
        Act of Independence
       </a>
       was signed on 16 February 1918, declaring the founding of the modern Republic of Lithuania. In the midst of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
        Second World War
       </a>
       , Lithuania was first
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">
        occupied by the Soviet Union
       </a>
       and then by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Lithuania_by_Nazi_Germany" title="Occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany">
        Nazi Germany
       </a>
       . As World War II neared its end and the Germans retreated, the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">
        Soviet Union reoccupied Lithuania
       </a>
       . On 11 March 1990, a year before the formal
       <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">
        dissolution of the Soviet Union
       </a>
       , Lithuania became the first
       <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">
        Soviet republic
       </a>
       to declare itself independent, resulting in
       <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">
        the restoration of an independent State of Lithuania
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       , a full member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        Eurozone
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">
        Schengen Agreement
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       . It is also a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">
        Nordic Investment Bank
       </a>
       , and part of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NB8" title="NB8">
        Nordic-Baltic
       </a>
       cooperation of
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        Northern European
       </a>
       countries. The United Nations
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       lists Lithuania as a "very high human development" country.
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Lithuania" title="Name of Lithuania">
        Name of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="316" data-file-width="600" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/220px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/330px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg/440px-Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lietuvos_vardas._The_first_name_of_Lithuania_in_writing_1009.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuania's name in writing 1009
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The first known record of the name of Lithuania (
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="lt">
         Lietuva
        </span>
       </i>
       ) is in a 9 March 1009 story of
       <a href="/wiki/Bruno_of_Querfurt" title="Bruno of Querfurt">
        Saint Bruno
       </a>
       recorded in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quedlinburg_Chronicle" title="Quedlinburg Chronicle">
        Quedlinburg Chronicle
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
        Latin
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="la">
         Annales Quedlinburgenses
        </span>
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Chronicle recorded a Latinized form of the name Lietuva:
       <i>
        Litua
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [litua]
       </span>
       ). Due to the lack of reliable evidence, true meaning of the name is unknown. Nowadays, scholars still debate the meaning of the word and there are a few persuasive versions.
      </p>
      <p>
       There have been several attempts to associate
       <i>
        Lietuva
       </i>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">
        Celtic
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toponyms" title="Toponyms">
        toponyms
       </a>
       , and with Latin or
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       words, but these attempts all lack strong linguistic support. According to a widespread popular belief, the word
       <i>
        Lietuva
       </i>
       (Lithuania) originated from the Lithuanian words
       <i>
        lyti
       </i>
       (to rain) and
       <i>
        lietus
       </i>
       (rain).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, there is no serious scientific support for this theory. Since the word
       <i>
        Lietuva
       </i>
       has a suffix (-
       <i>
        uva
       </i>
       ), the original word should have no suffix. A likely candidate is
       <i>
        Lietā
       </i>
       . Because many
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_language" title="Baltic language">
        Baltic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
        ethnonyms
       </a>
       originated from
       <a href="/wiki/Hydronym" title="Hydronym">
        hydronyms
       </a>
       , linguists have searched for its origin among local hydronyms. Usually such names evolved through the following process: hydronym → toponym →
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
        ethnonym
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas2_16-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zigmas2-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A small river not far from
       <a href="/wiki/Kernav%C4%97" title="Kernavė">
        Kernavė
       </a>
       , the core area of the
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Duchy of Lithuania">
        early Lithuanian state
       </a>
       and a possible first capital of the would-be
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">
        Grand Duchy of Lithuania
       </a>
       , is usually credited as the source of the name. This river's original name is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lietava_River" title="Lietava River">
        Lietava
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas2_16-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zigmas2-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As time passed, the suffix -
       <i>
        ava
       </i>
       could have changed into -
       <i>
        uva
       </i>
       , as the two are from the same suffix branch. The river flows in the lowlands and easily spills over its banks, therefore the traditional Lithuanian form
       <i>
        liet
       </i>
       - could be directly translated as
       <i>
        lietis
       </i>
       (to spill), of the root derived from the Proto-Indo-European *
       <i>
        leyǝ-
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is believed that
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rimgaudas" title="Rimgaudas">
        Rimgaudas
       </a>
       (father of
       <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">
        Mindaugas
       </a>
       ) ruled the area of Kernavė.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the river is very small and some find it improbable that such a small and local object could have lent its name to an entire nation. On the other hand, such a fact is not unprecedented in world history.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas_19-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zigmas-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       While the word's etymology continues to be debated, scientists agree that the primary origins of the ethnonym were the Lithuanian forms
       <i>
        *Lētuvā/Lietuva
       </i>
       , which were then used by different languages, including Slavic. It is very unlikely for the name to have derived from a Slavic language, since the Slavic -
       <i>
        i
       </i>
       - (и) could never be transliterated into the Lithuanian diphthong -
       <i>
        ie
       </i>
       -.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zigmas_19-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zigmas-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Among other etymologies of the name of Lithuania there is Artūras Dubonis' hypothesis,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that Lietuva relates to the word *
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lei%C4%8Diai" title="Leičiai">
         leičiai
        </a>
       </i>
       (plural of
       <i>
        leitis
       </i>
       , a social group in the early Grand Duchy of Lithuania). From the middle of the 13th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Lei%C4%8Diai" title="Leičiai">
        leičiai
       </a>
       were a distinct social group of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       society subordinate to the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_rulers_of_Lithuania" title="List of rulers of Lithuania">
        Lithuanian ruler
       </a>
       or the state itself. They were living in the
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Voivodeship" title="Vilnius Voivodeship">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Trakai_Voivodeship" title="Trakai Voivodeship">
        Trakai Voivodeships
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Manor" title="Manor">
        manors
       </a>
       . Possibly, already in the 14th century part of them became
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajorai" title="Bajorai">
         bajorai
        </a>
       </i>
       . Another meaning of
       <i>
        leičiai
       </i>
       is used in the 14th – 16th centuries historical sources as a Lithuanians
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
        ethnonym
       </a>
       . It is believed that occasionally all Lithuanians were called using it (except for
       <a href="/wiki/Samogitians" title="Samogitians">
        Samogitians
       </a>
       ). Term
       <i>
        leiši
       </i>
       (plural of
       <i>
        leitis
       </i>
       ), as a
       <a href="/wiki/Synonym" title="Synonym">
        synonym
       </a>
       to the Lithuanians ethnonym (beside the newer
       <i>
        lietuvietis
       </i>
       ), to this day maintained
       <a href="/wiki/Latvians" title="Latvians">
        Latvians
       </a>
       who are speaking with a very closely related
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">
        Latvian language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Lithuania" title="History of Lithuania">
        History of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistoric">
        Prehistoric
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The first people settled in the territory of Lithuania after the
       <a href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">
        last glacial period
       </a>
       in the 10th millennium BC. Over a millennium, the
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">
        Indo-Europeans
       </a>
       , who arrived in the 3rd – 2nd millennium BC, mixed with the local population and formed various
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_tribes" title="Baltic tribes">
        Baltic tribes
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval">
        Medieval
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">
        Grand Duchy of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LithuaniaHistory.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1743" data-file-width="1519" height="459" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/LithuaniaHistory.png/400px-LithuaniaHistory.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/LithuaniaHistory.png/600px-LithuaniaHistory.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/LithuaniaHistory.png/800px-LithuaniaHistory.png 2x" width="400"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LithuaniaHistory.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Changes in the territory of Lithuania from the 13th century to the present day. At its peak, Lithuania was the largest state in
         <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
          Europe
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
          <a href="#cite_note-23">
           [23]
          </a>
         </sup>
         Lithuania's strength was its extraordinary
         <a href="/wiki/Toleration" title="Toleration">
          toleration
         </a>
         of various
         <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">
          cultures
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">
          religions
         </a>
         .
         <a href="/wiki/Statutes_of_Lithuania#Third_Statute" title="Statutes of Lithuania">
          The Third Statute of Lithuania
         </a>
         removed term
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heretic" title="Heretic">
          heretic
         </a>
         as a
         <a href="/wiki/Religious_discrimination" title="Religious discrimination">
          discrimination
         </a>
         in 1588 and the state had no
         <a href="/wiki/Inquisition" title="Inquisition">
          Inquisition
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
          <a href="#cite_note-24">
           [24]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2366" data-file-width="5194" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg/220px-Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg/330px-Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg/440px-Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kernav%C4%97_-_Hill_forts_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kernav%C4%97" title="Kernavė">
          Kernavė
         </a>
         hill forts mounds, the site of the early capital of the Grand Duchy (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
          UNESCO World Heritage Site
         </a>
         )
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle,_2009.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1832" data-file-width="3264" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/220px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/330px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg/440px-Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle%2C_2009.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Front_facade_of_the_Trakai_Island_Castle,_2009.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Trakai_Island_Castle" title="Trakai Island Castle">
          Trakai Island Castle
         </a>
         , the former residence of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Dukes of Lithuania">
          Grand Dukes
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Initially inhabited by fragmented Baltic tribes, in the 1230s the Lithuanian lands were united by
       <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">
        Mindaugas
       </a>
       , who was crowned as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Lithuania" title="King of Lithuania">
        King of Lithuania
       </a>
       on 6 July 1253.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voruta2001_25-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-voruta2001-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After his assassination in 1263,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_mythology" title="Lithuanian mythology">
        pagan Lithuania
       </a>
       was a target of the
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">
        Christian crusades
       </a>
       of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teutonic_Knights" title="Teutonic Knights">
        Teutonic Knights
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Order" title="Livonian Order">
        Livonian Order
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siege_of_Pil%C4%97nai" title="Siege of Pilėnai">
        Siege of Pilėnai
       </a>
       is noted for the Lithuanians' heroic defense against the intruders. Despite the devastating century-long struggle with the Orders, the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">
        Grand Duchy of Lithuania
       </a>
       expanded rapidly, overtaking former Slavic principalities of
       <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">
        Kievan Rus'
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       On 22 September 1236, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Saul%C4%97" title="Battle of Saulė">
        Battle of Saulė
       </a>
       between
       <a href="/wiki/Samogitians" title="Samogitians">
        Samogitians
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_Brothers_of_the_Sword" title="Livonian Brothers of the Sword">
        Livonian Brothers of the Sword
       </a>
       took place close to
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai" title="Šiauliai">
        Šiauliai
       </a>
       . The Livonian Brothers were smashed during it and their further conquest of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">
        Balts
       </a>
       lands were stopped.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The battle inspired rebellions among the
       <a href="/wiki/Curonians" title="Curonians">
        Curonians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Semigallians" title="Semigallians">
        Semigallians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Selonians" title="Selonians">
        Selonians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Oeselians" title="Oeselians">
        Oeselians
       </a>
       , tribes previously conquered by the Sword-Brothers. Some thirty years' worth of conquests on the left bank of
       <a href="/wiki/Daugava" title="Daugava">
        Daugava
       </a>
       were lost.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2000, the Lithuanian and Latvian parliaments declared 22 September to be the Day of Baltic Unity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1240" data-file-width="2110" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg/220px-%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg/330px-%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg/440px-%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D0%BD%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C_%D0%94%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%BE_%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%83_%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D1%96_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D1%85_%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%85.1362_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuanians crushing the
         <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">
          Golden Horde
         </a>
         during the
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Blue_Waters" title="Battle of Blue Waters">
          Battle of Blue Waters
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1362 or 1363, Grand Duke
       <a href="/wiki/Algirdas" title="Algirdas">
        Algirdas
       </a>
       marched between lower
       <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">
        Dnieper
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Bug" title="Southern Bug">
        Southern Bug
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kiaupa_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kiaupa-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       First, Algirdas captured remaining territories of the
       <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Chernigov" title="Principality of Chernigov">
        Principality of Chernigov
       </a>
       – the bulk of the territory, including the capital in
       <a href="/wiki/Bryansk" title="Bryansk">
        Bryansk
       </a>
       , fell under Lithuanian control around 1357–1358. The Lithuanians then attacked Korshev (Коршов), an unidentified fortress located in the upper reaches of the
       <a href="/wiki/Bystraya_Sosna_River" title="Bystraya Sosna River">
        Bystraya Sosna River
       </a>
       , tributary of the
       <a href="/wiki/Don_River_(Russia)" title="Don River (Russia)">
        Don River
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baran_30-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-baran-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is believed that Algirdas further conquered territories of the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Principality_of_Pereslavl" title="Principality of Pereslavl">
        Principality of Pereslavl
       </a>
       . The area belonged to Crimean ulus which was engaged in a campaign against
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Sarai" title="New Sarai">
        New Sarai
       </a>
       and could not organize effective resistance. Three Tatar
       <a href="/wiki/Bey" title="Bey">
        beys
       </a>
       of Podolia gathered an army to resist the invasion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baran_30-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-baran-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanians smashed the
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">
        Golden Horde
       </a>
       forces during the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Blue_Waters" title="Battle of Blue Waters">
        Battle of Blue Waters
       </a>
       and stopped its further expansion in the present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
        Ukraine
       </a>
       . The victory brought the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">
        Kiev
       </a>
       and a large part of present-day Ukraine, including sparsely populated
       <a href="/wiki/Podolia" title="Podolia">
        Podolia
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dykra" title="Dykra">
        Dykra
       </a>
       , under the control of the expanding Grand Duchy of Lithuania. The duchy also gained access to the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       . Algirdas left
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Olgerdovich" title="Vladimir Olgerdovich">
        his son Vladimir
       </a>
       in Kiev.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kiaupa_29-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kiaupa-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After taking Kiev, Lithuania became a direct neighbor and rival of the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">
        Grand Duchy of Moscow
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By the end of the 14th century, Lithuania was one of the largest countries in Europe and included present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">
        Belarus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
        Ukraine
       </a>
       , and parts of
       <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
        Poland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The geopolitical situation between the west and the east determined the multicultural and multi-confessional character of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. The ruling elite practised religious tolerance and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chancery_Slavonic" title="Chancery Slavonic">
        Chancery Slavonic
       </a>
       language was used as an auxiliary language to the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       for official documents.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1385, the Grand Duke
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jogaila" title="Jogaila">
        Jogaila
       </a>
       accepted Poland's offer to become its king.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jogaila" title="Jogaila">
        Jogaila
       </a>
       embarked on gradual
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Lithuania" title="Christianization of Lithuania">
        Christianization of Lithuania
       </a>
       and established a
       <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">
        personal union
       </a>
       between Poland and Lithuania. It implied that Lithuania, the fiercely independent land, was one of the last
       <a href="/wiki/Romuva_(religion)" title="Romuva (religion)">
        pagan
       </a>
       areas of Europe to adopt Christianity.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jan_Matejko,_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1553" data-file-width="3571" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/220px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/330px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg/440px-Jan_Matejko%2C_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jan_Matejko,_Bitwa_pod_Grunwaldem.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">
          Battle of Grunwald
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great" title="Vytautas the Great">
          Vytautas the Great
         </a>
         in the centre
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After two civil wars,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great" title="Vytautas the Great">
        Vytautas the Great
       </a>
       became the Grand Duke of Lithuania in 1392. During his reign, Lithuania reached the peak of its territorial expansion, centralization of the state began, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_nobility" title="Lithuanian nobility">
        Lithuanian nobility
       </a>
       became increasingly prominent in state politics. In the great
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Vorskla_River" title="Battle of the Vorskla River">
        Battle of the Vorskla River
       </a>
       in 1399, the combined forces of
       <a href="/wiki/Tokhtamysh" title="Tokhtamysh">
        Tokhtamysh
       </a>
       and Vytautas were defeated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">
        Mongols
       </a>
       . Thanks to close cooperation, the armies of Lithuania and Poland achieved a great victory over the Teutonic Knights in 1410 at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Grunwald" title="Battle of Grunwald">
        Battle of Grunwald
       </a>
       , one of the largest battles of medieval Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lane_33-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lane-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In January 1429, at the
       <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Lutsk" title="Congress of Lutsk">
        Congress of Lutsk
       </a>
       Vytautas received the title of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Lithuania" title="King of Lithuania">
        King of Lithuania
       </a>
       with the backing of
       <a href="/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor">
        Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor
       </a>
       , but the envoys who were transporting the crown were stopped by Polish
       <a href="/wiki/Magnate" title="Magnate">
        magnates
       </a>
       in autumn of 1430. Another crown was sent, but Vytautas died in the
       <a href="/wiki/Trakai_Island_Castle" title="Trakai Island Castle">
        Trakai Island Castle
       </a>
       several days before it reached Lithuania. He was buried in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Vilnius" title="Cathedral of Vilnius">
        Cathedral of Vilnius
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After the deaths of Jogaila and Vytautas, the Lithuanian nobility attempted to break the union between
       <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
        Poland
       </a>
       and Lithuania, independently selecting Grand Dukes from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jagiellon_dynasty" title="Jagiellon dynasty">
        Jagiellon dynasty
       </a>
       . But, at the end of the 15th century, Lithuania was forced to seek a closer alliance with Poland when the growing power of the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">
        Grand Duchy of Moscow
       </a>
       threatened Lithuania's Russian principalities and sparked the
       <a href="/wiki/Muscovite%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Wars" title="Muscovite–Lithuanian Wars">
        Muscovite–Lithuanian Wars
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">
        Livonian War
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Autor_nieznany_(malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego),_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2506" data-file-width="3966" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/220px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/330px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg/440px-Autor_nieznany_%28malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego%29%2C_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Autor_nieznany_(malarz_z_kr%C4%99gu_Lukasa_Cranacha_Starszego),_Bitwa_pod_Orsz%C4%85.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         During the
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Orsha" title="Battle of Orsha">
          Battle of Orsha
         </a>
         in 1514 Lithuanians hopelessly trounced the
         <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">
          Grand Duchy of Moscow
         </a>
         forces
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 8 September 1514,
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Orsha" title="Battle of Orsha">
        Battle of Orsha
       </a>
       between Lithuanians, commanded by the
       <a href="/wiki/Hetmans_of_the_Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Hetmans of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Grand Hetman
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Konstanty_Ostrogski" title="Konstanty Ostrogski">
        Konstanty Ostrogski
       </a>
       , and Muscovites was fought. According to
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rerum_Moscoviticarum_Commentarii" title="Rerum Moscoviticarum Commentarii">
         Rerum Moscoviticarum Commentarii
        </a>
       </i>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Sigismund_von_Herberstein" title="Sigismund von Herberstein">
        Sigismund von Herberstein
       </a>
       , the primary source for information on the battle, the much smaller army of Poland–Lithuania (under 30,000 men) defeated a force of 80,000 Muscovite soldiers, capturing their camp and commander.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The battle destroyed a military alliance against Lithuania and Poland. Thousands of Muscovites were captured as prisoners and used as laborers in the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_palaces_and_manor_houses_in_Lithuania" title="List of palaces and manor houses in Lithuania">
        Lithuanian manors
       </a>
       , while Konstanty Ostrogski delivered the captured Muscovite flags to the Cathedral of Vilnius.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Livonian War was ceased for ten years with a
       <a href="/wiki/Truce_of_Yam-Zapolsky" title="Truce of Yam-Zapolsky">
        Truce of Yam-Zapolsky
       </a>
       signed on 15 January 1582 according to which the already
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
       </a>
       recovered
       <a href="/wiki/Livonia" title="Livonia">
        Livonia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">
        Polotsk
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Velizh" title="Velizh">
        Velizh
       </a>
       , but transferred
       <a href="/wiki/Velikiye_Luki" title="Velikiye Luki">
        Velikiye Luki
       </a>
       to the
       <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">
        Tsardom of Russia
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truce" title="Truce">
        truce
       </a>
       was extended for twenty years in 1600, when a
       <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_mission" title="Diplomatic mission">
        diplomatic mission
       </a>
       to Moscow led by
       <a href="/wiki/Lew_Sapieha" title="Lew Sapieha">
        Lew Sapieha
       </a>
       concluded negotiations with Tsar
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_Godunov" title="Boris Godunov">
        Boris Godunov
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The truce was broken when
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%9318)" title="Polish–Muscovite War (1605–18)">
        the Poles invaded Muscovy in 1605
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Modern">
        Modern
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg/220px-Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg/330px-Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg/440px-Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zamek_Dolny_w_Wilnie.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania" title="Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania">
          Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania
         </a>
         in the modern capital
         <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
          Vilnius
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
       </a>
       was created in 1569. As a member of the Commonwealth, Lithuania retained its institutions, including a separate army, currency, and statutory laws.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Eventually
       <a href="/wiki/Polonization" title="Polonization">
        Polonization
       </a>
       affected all aspects of Lithuanian life: politics, language, culture, and national identity. From the mid-16th to the mid-17th centuries, culture, arts, and education flourished, fueled by the
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
        Renaissance
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">
        Protestant Reformation
       </a>
       . From 1573, the Kings of Poland and Grand Dukes of Lithuania were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_election_(Polish_throne)" title="Free election (Polish throne)">
        elected by the nobility
       </a>
       , who were granted ever increasing
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Liberty" title="Golden Liberty">
        Golden Liberties
       </a>
       . These liberties, especially the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Liberum_veto" title="Liberum veto">
         liberum veto
        </a>
       </i>
       , led to anarchy and the eventual dissolution of the state.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kazimierz_Wojniakowski,_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1686" data-file-width="2429" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg/220px-Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg/330px-Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg/440px-Kazimierz_Wojniakowski%2C_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kazimierz_Wojniakowski,_Uchwalenie_Konstytucji_3_Maja.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Great_Sejm" title="Great Sejm">
          Great Sejm
         </a>
         and Senate adopts
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791">
          Constitution of 3 May 1791
         </a>
         , which is claimed to be the second oldest
         <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">
          constitution
         </a>
         in the world after the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Constitution" title="U.S. Constitution">
          U.S. Constitution
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_May_3,_1791" title="Constitution of May 3, 1791">
        Constitution of 3 May 1791
       </a>
       was adopted by the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Sejm" title="Great Sejm">
        Great Sejm
       </a>
       (parliament) of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth trying to save the state. The legislation was designed to redress the Commonwealth's political defects due to the system of Golden Liberties, also known as the "Nobles' Democracy," had conferred disproportionate rights on the nobility (szlachta) and over time had corrupted politics. The constitution sought to supplant the prevailing anarchy fostered by some of the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Magnates_of_Poland_and_Lithuania" title="Magnates of Poland and Lithuania">
        magnates
       </a>
       with a more democratic
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
        constitutional monarchy
       </a>
       . It introduced elements of political equality between townspeople and nobility, and placed the peasants under the protection of the government, thus mitigating the worst abuses of
       <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">
        serfdom
       </a>
       . It banned parliamentary institutions such as the
       <i>
        liberum veto
       </i>
       , which had put the Sejm at the mercy of any deputy who could revoke all the legislation that had been passed by that Sejm. It was drafted in relation to a copy of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Constitution" title="U.S. Constitution">
        U.S. Constitution
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Others have called it the world's second-oldest codified national governmental constitution after the 1787
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Constitution" title="U.S. Constitution">
        U.S. Constitution
       </a>
       . The 1787 U.S. Constitution was actually the first governmental constitution, introducing the clear division of the executive, legislative and judiciary powers, accordingly with
       <a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">
        the legal and philosophical values
       </a>
       influential in the
       <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">
        Enlightenment
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Wars" title="Northern Wars">
        Northern Wars
       </a>
       (1655–1661), the Lithuanian territory and economy were devastated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Empire" title="Swedish Empire">
        Swedish
       </a>
       army. Before it could fully recover, Lithuania was ravaged during the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">
        Great Northern War
       </a>
       (1700–1721). The war,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_plague_during_the_Great_Northern_War" title="The plague during the Great Northern War">
        a plague
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Frost_of_1709" title="Great Frost of 1709">
        a famine
       </a>
       caused the deaths of approximately 40% of the country's population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Foreign powers, especially Russia, became dominant in the domestic politics of the Commonwealth. Numerous factions among the nobility used the Golden Liberties to prevent any reforms. Eventually,
       <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">
        the Commonwealth was partitioned
       </a>
       in 1772, 1792, and 1795 by the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">
        Prussia
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habsburg_Austria" title="Habsburg Austria">
        Habsburg Austria
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:111px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bielinis.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="150" data-file-width="109" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c7/Bielinis.jpg" width="109"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bielinis.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Jurgis_Bielinis" title="Jurgis Bielinis">
          Jurgis Bielinis
         </a>
         , one of the most famous
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Book_smuggler" title="Book smuggler">
          book smugglers
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The largest area of Lithuanian territory became part of the Russian Empire. After unsuccessful
       <a href="/wiki/November_Uprising" title="November Uprising">
        uprisings in 1831
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/January_Uprising" title="January Uprising">
        1863
       </a>
       , the Tsarist authorities implemented a number of
       <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">
        Russification
       </a>
       policies. They
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_press_ban" title="Lithuanian press ban">
        banned the Lithuanian press
       </a>
       , closed cultural and educational institutions, and made Lithuania part of a new administrative region called
       <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Krai" title="Northwestern Krai">
        Northwestern Krai
       </a>
       . The Russification failed owing to an extensive network of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Book_smuggler" title="Book smuggler">
        book smugglers
       </a>
       and secret Lithuanian home schooling.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">
        Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)
       </a>
       , when German diplomats assigned what were seen as Russian spoils of war to Turkey, the relationship between Russia and the
       <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">
        German Empire
       </a>
       became complicated. The Russian Empire resumed the construction of fortresses at its western borders for defence against a potential invasion from Germany in the West. On 7 July 1879 the
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia" title="Alexander II of Russia">
        Russian Emperor Alexander II
       </a>
       approved of a proposal from the Russian military leadership to build the largest "first-class" defensive structure in the entire state – the 65 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (25 sq mi)
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Fortress" title="Kaunas Fortress">
        Kaunas Fortress
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kauno_tvirtovė_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kauno_tvirtovė-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Large numbers of Lithuanians went to the United States in 1867–1868 after a
       <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">
        famine
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Revival" title="Lithuanian National Revival">
        Lithuanian National Revival
       </a>
       laid the foundations of the modern Lithuanian nation and independent Lithuania.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="20th_and_21st_centuries">
        20th and 21st centuries
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="655" data-file-width="945" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/220px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/330px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg/440px-Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Signatarai.Signatories_of_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The original 20 members of the
         <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Lithuania" title="Council of Lithuania">
          Council of Lithuania
         </a>
         after signing the
         <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">
          Act of Independence of Lithuania
         </a>
         , 16 February 1918.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       rapidly reached the territory of Lithuania. Germany’s push to the east drove the forces of the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       to retreat. By the end of 1915, Germany occupied the entire territory of Lithuania and
       <a href="/wiki/Courland" title="Courland">
        Courland
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A new administrative entity,
       <a href="/wiki/Ober_Ost" title="Ober Ost">
        Ober Ost
       </a>
       (short for
       <i>
        Oberbefehlshaber der gesamten Deutschen Streitkräfte im Osten
       </i>
       , which is German for "Supreme Commander of All German Forces in the East"), was established. Lithuanians lost all political rights they had gained: personal freedom was restricted, and at the beginning the Lithuanian press was banned.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       However, the Lithuanian intelligentsia tried to take advantage of the existing geopolitical situation and began to look for opportunities to restore Lithuania’s independence. On 18–22 September 1917, the
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Conference" title="Vilnius Conference">
        Vilnius Conference
       </a>
       elected the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Lithuania" title="Council of Lithuania">
        Council of Lithuania
       </a>
       . At the conference, it was decided to re-establish the state of Lithuania with its ethnographic borders and the capital of
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Smetona" title="Antanas Smetona">
        Antanas Smetona
       </a>
       was elected the chairman of the Council (
       <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Basanavi%C4%8Dius" title="Jonas Basanavičius">
        Jonas Basanavičius
       </a>
       became the chairman only on 16 February 1918). Following the geopolitical situation, on 11 December 1917, the Council of Lithuania adopted a resolution announcing the restoration of an independent state of Lithuania with the capital in Vilnius and severing all ties that had ever been established with other countries and calling for the eternal union with Germany. The latter statement was rejected by some of the members of the Council, forcing
       <a href="/wiki/Mykolas_Bir%C5%BEi%C5%A1ka" title="Mykolas Biržiška">
        Mykolas Biržiška
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Steponas_Kairys" title="Steponas Kairys">
        Steponas Kairys
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Narutowicz" title="Stanisław Narutowicz">
        Stanislovas Narutavičius
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Petras_Vilei%C5%A1is" title="Petras Vileišis">
        Petras Vileišis
       </a>
       to leave the organization.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As
       <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       was losing the war, a decision had been made to abandon this union. A resolution adopted on
       <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania" title="Act of Independence of Lithuania">
        16 February 1918,
       </a>
       was recognized as the Act of Independence of Lithuania. It restored an independent state of Lithuania governed by democratic principles, with
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       as its capital. The Act also stated that Lithuania’s relations with other countries will be established by the democratically elected
       <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Lithuania" title="Constituent Assembly of Lithuania">
        Constituent Assembly of Lithuania
       </a>
       . The state of Lithuania which had been built within the framework of the Act lasted from 1918 until 1940.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In July 1918, resisting the plans of those who welcomed the annexation by Germany the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Lithuania" title="Council of Lithuania">
        Council of Lithuania
       </a>
       elected Prince Wilhelm of Urach, Count of
       <a href="/wiki/W%C3%BCrttemberg" title="Württemberg">
        Württemberg
       </a>
       , as King of Lithuania, with a regnal name of
       <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Karl,_Duke_of_Urach" title="Wilhelm Karl, Duke of Urach">
        Mindaugas II
       </a>
       . However, following the capitulation of Germany in November 1918, the idea of the monarchy was abandoned, leaving the question about the ruling system to the constituent assembly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_(October_1926).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="379" data-file-width="263" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2a/Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_%28October_1926%29.jpg/150px-Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_%28October_1926%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2a/Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_%28October_1926%29.jpg/225px-Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_%28October_1926%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/2a/Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_%28October_1926%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_newspaper_Karys_front_page_(October_1926).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuanian newspaper with the title "Hey, world! We do not let it down without Vilnius!", 1926
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 11 November 1918, the first Provisional
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">
        Constitution of Lithuania
       </a>
       was written. At the same time, the army, the government, and other state institutions began to be organized. In 1919 the office of the presidency was introduced.
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Smetona" title="Antanas Smetona">
        Antanas Smetona
       </a>
       was elected the president of the state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1102" data-file-width="1469" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg/220px-Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg/330px-Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg/440px-Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaunas._Paminklas_zuvusiems_uz_laisve._2007-04-06.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier" title="Tomb of the Unknown Soldier">
          Tomb of the Unknown Soldier
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
         , dedicated to those who died in the
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Wars_of_Independence" title="Lithuanian Wars of Independence">
          Lithuanian Wars of Independence
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       As the
       <a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">
        Bolsheviks
       </a>
       were pushing for Vilnius, the government was moved to
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       , which had become a provisional capital. According to the Lithuanian Constitution of 1928 and 1938, the capital of the country was Vilnius. Trying to establish the statehood and draw state borders, Lithuania had to fight not only with the Bolsheviks, but also with the West Russian Volunteer Army or
       <a href="/wiki/West_Russian_Volunteer_Army" title="West Russian Volunteer Army">
        Bermontians
       </a>
       and the Poles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1487" data-file-width="971" height="337" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/220px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/330px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg/440px-Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antanas_Smetona_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Nationalist_Union" title="Lithuanian Nationalist Union">
          Nationalist
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Smetona" title="Antanas Smetona">
          Antanas Smetona
         </a>
         acquisition of authority in
         <a href="/wiki/1926_Lithuanian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1926 Lithuanian coup d'état">
          1926
         </a>
         led to a worship of the
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">
          Lithuanian nation
         </a>
         , its
         <a href="/wiki/History_of_Lithuania" title="History of Lithuania">
          history
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
          language
         </a>
         . Smetona’s regime was the first in Europe to trial
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nazis" title="Nazis">
          Nazis
         </a>
         even to
         <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment">
          death
         </a>
         and also the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communists" title="Communists">
          Communists
         </a>
         , who were both seen as a threat to the independence.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
          <a href="#cite_note-56">
           [56]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Bermontians were defeated in November 1919 at
       <a href="/wiki/Radvili%C5%A1kis" title="Radviliškis">
        Radviliškis
       </a>
       . The peace treaty with the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">
        Soviet Russia
       </a>
       was signed on 12 July 1920 that drew a frontier which placed the Vilnius district on the Lithuanian side.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheBalticStates31_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheBalticStates31-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_War" title="Polish–Lithuanian War">
        Polish–Lithuanian War
       </a>
       was stopped with a peace treaty signed between Lithuania and
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">
        Poland
       </a>
       on 7 October 1920, in
       <a href="/wiki/Suwa%C5%82ki_Agreement" title="Suwałki Agreement">
        Suwałki
       </a>
       that drew a
       <a href="/wiki/Demarcation_line" title="Demarcation line">
        line of demarcation
       </a>
       , which was incomplete but indicated that the Vilnius area would be part of Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheBalticStates31_57-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheBalticStates31-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, three days later the Poles broke the treaty as the
       <a href="/wiki/Lucjan_%C5%BBeligowski" title="Lucjan Żeligowski">
        Lucjan Żeligowski
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%BBeligowski%27s_Mutiny" title="Żeligowski's Mutiny">
        troops seized and occupied the Vilnius Region
       </a>
       and drove out the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Armed_Forces" title="Lithuanian Armed Forces">
        Lithuanian forces
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheBalticStates31_57-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-TheBalticStates31-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanians were able to stop their push deeper into the territory only on 21-22 November at
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0irvintos" title="Širvintos">
        Širvintos
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Giedrai%C4%8Diai" title="Giedraičiai">
        Giedraičiai
       </a>
       . Notwithstanding, Vilnius remained to be part of Poland becoming the cornerstone of Lithuania’s foreign policy, and causing vast Lithuanians anger towards the Poles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Żeligowski proclaimed the Independence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Central_Lithuania" title="Republic of Central Lithuania">
        Republic of Central Lithuania
       </a>
       on 12 October 1920 with Wilno as its capital. On 8 January 1922, Żeligowski organized
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Central_Lithuania_general_election,_1922" title="Republic of Central Lithuania general election, 1922">
        elections to the Vilnius Sejm
       </a>
       and passed his powers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iskauskas_60-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Iskauskas-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The elections were not recognized by the
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
        League of Nations
       </a>
       , Lithuania and boycotted by Lithuanians, most of the
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       and some
       <a href="/wiki/Belarusians" title="Belarusians">
        Belarusians
       </a>
       . Poles were the only major ethnic group out of which the majority of people voted.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 24 March 1922, the newly elected parliament decided to submit the area to Poland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iskauskas_60-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Iskauskas-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 15 May 1920, the first meeting of the democratically elected
       <a href="/wiki/Constituent_assembly" title="Constituent assembly">
        constituent assembly
       </a>
