       took place. The documents it adopted, i. e. the temporary (1920) and permanent (1922) constitutions of Lithuania, strove to regulate the life of the new state. Land, finance, and educational reforms started to be implemented. The currency of Lithuania, the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_litas" title="Lithuanian litas">
        Lithuanian litas
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was introduced. The
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University" title="Vytautas Magnus University">
        University of Lithuania
       </a>
       was opened.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All major public institutions had been established. As Lithuania began to gain stability, foreign countries started to recognize it. In 1921 Lithuania was admitted to the
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
        League of Nations
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="269" data-file-width="369" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d0/Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg/220px-Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d0/Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg/330px-Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/d0/Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas_in_Kaunas.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palace_of_Justice_and_the_Seimas" title="Palace of Justice and the Seimas">
          Palace of Justice and the Seimas
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
         , decorated with the
         <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Lithuania" title="Flag of Lithuania">
          tricolors
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The first Parliament of Lithuania or
       <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
        Seimas
       </a>
       was elected in October 1922.
       <a href="/wiki/Aleksandras_Stulginskis" title="Aleksandras Stulginskis">
        Aleksandras Stulginskis
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       was elected as a president. One of the most important achievements of that time was the incorporation of
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaipėda Region">
        Klaipėda Region
       </a>
       into the territory of Lithuania in 1923 and its international recognition in 1924. The Third Seimas elected
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Grinius" title="Kazys Grinius">
        Kazys Grinius
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       a member of
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Popular_Peasants%27_Union" title="Lithuanian Popular Peasants' Union">
        Lithuanian Popular Peasants’ Union
       </a>
       , as the country’s president. However, his leadership did not last long.
      </p>
      <p>
       On 17 December 1926, a military
       <a href="/wiki/1926_Lithuanian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1926 Lithuanian coup d'état">
        coup d’état
       </a>
       took place resulting in the replacement of the democratically elected government with a conservative authoritarian government led by Antanas Smetona.
       <a href="/wiki/Augustinas_Voldemaras" title="Augustinas Voldemaras">
        Augustinas Voldemaras
       </a>
       was appointed to form a government. The so-called authoritarian phase had begun strengthening the influence of one party, the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Nationalist_Union" title="Lithuanian Nationalist Union">
        Lithuanian Nationalist Union
       </a>
       , in the country. In 1927, the Seimas was released.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A new constitution adopted in 1928, which consolidated presidential powers. Gradually the opposition parties were banned, the censorship was tightened, and the rights of national minorities were narrowed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The temporary capital Kaunas, which was nicknamed the
       <i>
        Little Paris
       </i>
       , and the country itself had a
       <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">
        Western
       </a>
       standard of living with sufficiently high salaries and low prices. At the time, qualified workers there were earning very similar
       <a href="/wiki/Real_wages" title="Real wages">
        real wages
       </a>
       as workers in
       <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
        Switzerland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
        France
       </a>
       , the country also had a surprisingly high
       <a href="/wiki/Rate_of_natural_increase" title="Rate of natural increase">
        natural increase in population
       </a>
       of 9.7 and the
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_production" title="Industrial production">
        industrial production
       </a>
       of Lithuania increased by 160% from 1913 to 1940.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The situation was aggravated by the global economic crisis.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The purchase price of agricultural products had declined significantly. In 1935, farmers began strikes in
       <a href="/wiki/Suvalkija" title="Suvalkija">
        Suvalkija
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dz%C5%ABkija" title="Dzūkija">
        Dzūkija
       </a>
       . In addition to economic ones, political demands were made. The government cruelly suppressed the unrest. In the spring of 1936, four peasants were sentenced to death for starting the riots.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="1939.E2.80.931940">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="1939–1940">
        1939–1940
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        Occupation of the Baltic states
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Initially prior the
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , Lithuania declared
       <a href="/wiki/Neutral_powers_during_World_War_II" title="Neutral powers during World War II">
        neutrality
       </a>
       and its
       <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
        Seimas
       </a>
       passed the neutrality laws.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Though, on the eve of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , as the geopolitical situation in the region started to change, Lithuania was forced to accept the ultimatums of the neighboring countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 17 March 1938, Poland delivered an ultimatum calling for diplomatic relations. Although practically it meant Poland’s “refusal” of
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       , Lithuania had also sought to restore relations with its neighbor, and accepted the ultimatum. On 20 March 1939, Lithuania was handed an ultimatum by
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Nazi Germany
       </a>
       . A request was made to transfer the
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region" title="Klaipėda Region">
        Klaipėda Region
       </a>
       to Nazi Germany. Two days later, without seeing the way out, the Lithuanian government signed the agreement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="654" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/330px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg/440px-Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_delegation_1939-10-07.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuanian delegation before departing to Moscow, where they later were tactically forced to sign the
         <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Mutual_Assistance_Treaty" title="Soviet–Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty">
          Soviet–Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Another large neighbor — the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       also began preparing for the occupation of the Lithuania's territory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baltic_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-baltic-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 7 October 1939 the Lithuanian delegation departed to
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       where they later had to sign the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Mutual_Assistance_Treaty" title="Soviet–Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty">
        Soviet–Lithuanian Mutual Assistance Treaty
       </a>
       due to the unfavorable situation. The treaty resulted in five Soviet military bases with 20,000 troops established across Lithuania in exchange for the Lithuania's historical capital Vilnius. According to the Lithuanian Minister of National Defence
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Musteikis" title="Kazys Musteikis">
        Kazys Musteikis
       </a>
       , Lithuanian Minister of Foreign Affairs
       <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Urb%C5%A1ys" title="Juozas Urbšys">
        Juozas Urbšys
       </a>
       initially told that Lithuanians refuses
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Region" title="Vilnius Region">
        Vilnius Region
       </a>
       as well as the Russian garrisons, however then nervous
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">
        Joseph Stalin
       </a>
       replied that "No matter if you take Vilnius or not, the Russian garrisons will enter Lithuania anyway".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He also informed Juozas Urbšys about the
       <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        Soviet–German secret protocols
       </a>
       and showed maps of the spheres of influence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two of the military bases with thousands of Soviet soldiers were established close to
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Prienai" title="Prienai">
        Prienai
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gai%C5%BEi%C5%ABnai" title="Gaižiūnai">
        Gaižiūnai
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite regaining the beloved historical capital, the Presidency and the Government remained in Kaunas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_(2017).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg/220px-Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg/330px-Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg/440px-Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_%282017%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Historical_Presidential_Palace_in_Kaunas_(2017).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Historical_Presidential_Palace,_Kaunas" title="Historical Presidential Palace, Kaunas">
          Presidential Palace
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
         , where the last meeting of the independent
         <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Lithuania" title="Government of Lithuania">
          Government of Lithuania
         </a>
         took place on the night of 14 June 1940
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1608" data-file-width="1968" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg/220px-Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg/330px-Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg/440px-Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Communists_with_the_Lithuanian_Army_soldiers.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet" title="Soviet">
          Soviet
         </a>
         political leader (without
         <a href="/wiki/Shoulder_strap#Military_shoulder_strap" title="Shoulder strap">
          military shoulder straps
         </a>
         ) and the marionette
         <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Seimas" title="People's Seimas">
          People's Seimas
         </a>
         member (with red rose in his jacket
         <a href="/wiki/Lapel" title="Lapel">
          lapel
         </a>
         ) announces to the Lithuanian People's Army
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-commissioned_officers" title="Non-commissioned officers">
          non-commissioned officers
         </a>
         that "soon you will become members of the glorious
         <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
          Red Army
         </a>
         " in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
         , 1940
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The next step made by the USSR was accusations of the abduction of the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       soldiers in Lithuania. Although the Lithuanian government denied such allegations, the tensions became heightened on both sides.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 14 June 1940, the USSR issued an
       <a href="/wiki/1940_Soviet_ultimatum_to_Lithuania" title="1940 Soviet ultimatum to Lithuania">
        ultimatum
       </a>
       to Lithuania, demanding to replace the government and allow Red Army's units to enter the territory of Lithuania without any prior agreements, which would mean the occupation of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBBG_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PBBG-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 14 June 1940 just before midnight, the last meeting of the Lithuanian Government was held in the
       <a href="/wiki/Historical_Presidential_Palace,_Kaunas" title="Historical Presidential Palace, Kaunas">
        Presidential Palace
       </a>
       , in Kaunas. During it, the Soviet's ultimatum was debated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       President
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Smetona" title="Antanas Smetona">
        Antanas Smetona
       </a>
       categorically declined to accept most of the ultimatum demands, argued for military resistance and was supported by
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Musteikis" title="Kazys Musteikis">
        Kazys Musteikis
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Konstantinas_%C5%A0akenis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Konstantinas Šakenis (page does not exist)">
        Konstantinas Šakenis
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konstantinas_%C5%A0akenis" title="lt:Konstantinas Šakenis">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Kazimieras_Jokantas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Kazimieras Jokantas (page does not exist)">
        Kazimieras Jokantas
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazimieras_Jokantas" title="lt:Kazimieras Jokantas">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       , however the Commander of the Armed Forces
       <a href="/wiki/Vincas_Vitkauskas" title="Vincas Vitkauskas">
        Vincas Vitkauskas
       </a>
       , Divisional general
       <a href="/wiki/Stasys_Ra%C5%A1tikis" title="Stasys Raštikis">
        Stasys Raštikis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Bizauskas" title="Kazys Bizauskas">
        Kazys Bizauskas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Merkys" title="Antanas Merkys">
        Antanas Merkys
       </a>
       and most of the Lithuanian Government members decided that it would be impossible, especially due to the previously stationed Soviet soldiers, and accepted the ultimatum.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On that night, the Soviet forces executed Lithuanian border guard
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Aleksandras_Barauskas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Aleksandras Barauskas (page does not exist)">
        Aleksandras Barauskas
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandras_Barauskas" title="lt:Aleksandras Barauskas">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       near the
       <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">
        Belarus
       </a>
       border.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the morning, the Lithuanian Government resigned while the president left the country to avoid the fate of the Soviet's puppet and hoping to form the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_in_exile" title="Government in exile">
        Government in exile
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Partizanai_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Partizanai-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Soon the Red Army flooded Lithuania through the
       <a href="/wiki/Belarus%E2%80%93Lithuania_border" title="Belarus–Lithuania border">
        Belarus–Lithuania border
       </a>
       with more than 200,000 soldiers and took control of the most important cities, including Kaunas where the heads of state resided. The Lithuanian Armed Forces were ordered not to resist and the Lithuanian Air Force remained on the ground.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the time, the Lithuanian Armed Forces had 26,084 soldiers (of which 1,728 officers) and 2,031 civil servants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Riflemen%27s_Union" title="Lithuanian Riflemen's Union">
        Lithuanian Riflemen's Union
       </a>
       , subordinate to the army commander, had over 62,000 members of which about 70% were farmers and agricultural workers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArmyDestruction_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ArmyDestruction-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After the occupation, the Soviets has immediately taken brutal actions against the high-ranking officials of the state. Both targets of the ultimatum: the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Lithuania)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Lithuania)">
        Minister of the Interior
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Sku%C4%8Das" title="Kazys Skučas">
        Kazys Skučas
       </a>
       and the Director of the State Security Department of Lithuania
       <a href="/wiki/Augustinas_Povilaitis" title="Augustinas Povilaitis">
        Augustinas Povilaitis
       </a>
       were transported to Moscow and later executed.
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Gustaitis" title="Antanas Gustaitis">
        Antanas Gustaitis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Bizauskas" title="Kazys Bizauskas">
        Kazys Bizauskas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Petrulis" title="Vytautas Petrulis">
        Vytautas Petrulis
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Kazimieras_Jokantas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Kazimieras Jokantas (page does not exist)">
        Kazimieras Jokantas
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazimieras_Jokantas" title="lt:Kazimieras Jokantas">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Jonas_Masili%C5%ABnas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Jonas Masiliūnas (page does not exist)">
        Jonas Masiliūnas
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Masili%C5%ABnas" title="lt:Jonas Masiliūnas">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Antanas_Tamo%C5%A1aitis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Antanas Tamošaitis (page does not exist)">
        Antanas Tamošaitis
       </a>
       <span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">
        (
        <a class="extiw" href="https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antanas_Tamo%C5%A1aitis_(1894)" title="lt:Antanas Tamošaitis (1894)">
         lt
        </a>
        )
       </span>
       also faced the fate of execution, while President
       <a href="/wiki/Aleksandras_Stulginskis" title="Aleksandras Stulginskis">
        Aleksandras Stulginskis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Urb%C5%A1ys" title="Juozas Urbšys">
        Juozas Urbšys
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Leonas_Bistras" title="Leonas Bistras">
        Leonas Bistras
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Merkys" title="Antanas Merkys">
        Antanas Merkys
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pranas_Dovydaitis" title="Pranas Dovydaitis">
        Pranas Dovydaitis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Petras_Klimas" title="Petras Klimas">
        Petras Klimas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Donatas_Malinauskas" title="Donatas Malinauskas">
        Donatas Malinauskas
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_deportations_from_Lithuania" title="Soviet deportations from Lithuania">
        thousands of others were deported
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Partizanai_87-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Partizanai-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Stasys Raštikis, persuaded by his wife, secretly crossed the German border. After realizing it,
       <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">
        NKVD
       </a>
       started terror against Raštikis family. His wife was separated from their 1-year-old daughter and brutally interrogated at
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Prison" title="Kaunas Prison">
        Kaunas Prison
       </a>
       , his old father Bernardas Raštikis, three daughters, two brothers and sister were deported to
       <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">
        Siberia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rastikis_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rastikis-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Soldiers,
       <a href="/wiki/Officer_(armed_forces)" title="Officer (armed forces)">
        officers
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Field_officer" title="Field officer">
        senior officers
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_generals_of_the_Lithuanian_Army" title="List of generals of the Lithuanian Army">
        generals
       </a>
       of the Lithuanian Army and LRU members, who were seen as a threat to the occupants, were quickly arrested, interrogated and released to the reserve, deported to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concentration_camp" title="Concentration camp">
        concentration camps
       </a>
       or executed, trying to avoid this many joined the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_partisans" title="Lithuanian partisans">
        Lithuanian partisans
       </a>
       forces. The army itself was firstly renamed to the Lithuanian People's Army, however later it was reorganized to the
       <a href="/wiki/29th_Rifle_Corps_(Soviet_Union)" title="29th Rifle Corps (Soviet Union)">
        29th Rifle Corps of the Soviet Union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArmyDestruction_91-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ArmyDestruction-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="1940.E2.80.931944">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="1940–1944">
        1940–1944
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/June_Uprising_in_Lithuania" title="June Uprising in Lithuania">
        June Uprising in Lithuania
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Lithuania_during_World_War_II" title="German occupation of Lithuania during World War II">
        German occupation of Lithuania during World War II
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Lithuania" title="The Holocaust in Lithuania">
        The Holocaust in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In Lithuania, World War II began on 15 June 1940, when the USSR occupied the territory of the country.
       <a href="/wiki/Sovietization_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Sovietization of the Baltic states">
        Sovietization
       </a>
       was started right away. New power banned opposition, its press, and organizations and also restricted ties with foreign countries. Shortly, on 17 June 1940 the puppetry
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Government_of_Lithuania" title="People's Government of Lithuania">
        People's Government of Lithuania
       </a>
       was formed, which consistently destroyed Lithuanian society, political institutions and opened the way for the
       <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Lithuania" title="Communist Party of Lithuania">
        Communist Party
       </a>
       to establish itself. In order to establish the legitimacy of the government and design the plans of Lithuania's "legal accession to the USSR", on July 1, the
       <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
        Seimas
       </a>
       of Lithuania was released and the forced elections with falsified results to the
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Seimas" title="People's Seimas">
        People's Seimas
       </a>
       were organized, which were won by the Lithuanian Labor People's Union and
       <a href="/wiki/Justas_Paleckis" title="Justas Paleckis">
        Justas Paleckis
       </a>
       was chosen as the illegal
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania" title="Prime Minister of Lithuania">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">
        President of Lithuania
       </a>
       . The new government obeyed the occupiers' proposal to "ask" the Soviet authorities to have Lithuania admitted to the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LRS1940_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LRS1940-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">
        Nationalization
       </a>
       of property and deportation of the local population was in full swing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBBG_83-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-PBBG-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="388" data-file-width="638" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg/220px-Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg/330px-Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg/440px-Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Session_of_the_Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Session of the
         <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania" title="Provisional Government of Lithuania">
          Provisional Government of Lithuania
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="532" data-file-width="800" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg/220px-LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg/330px-LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg/440px-LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LAF_fighters_leads_the_arrested_Commissar_of_the_Red_Army.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Activist_Front" title="Lithuanian Activist Front">
          LAF
         </a>
         activists leads the arrested
         <a href="/wiki/Commissar" title="Commissar">
          Commissar
         </a>
         of the
         <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
          Red Army
         </a>
         in Kaunas. Lithuanian rebels has killed thousands of the
         <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">
          Soviet's occupants
         </a>
         by suffering a low number of casualties.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General_Stasys_Rastikis_(1896%E2%80%931985).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="460" data-file-width="300" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/General_Stasys_Rastikis_%281896%E2%80%931985%29.jpg/150px-General_Stasys_Rastikis_%281896%E2%80%931985%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/General_Stasys_Rastikis_%281896%E2%80%931985%29.jpg/225px-General_Stasys_Rastikis_%281896%E2%80%931985%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d4/General_Stasys_Rastikis_%281896%E2%80%931985%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:General_Stasys_Rastikis_(1896%E2%80%931985).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Former Commander of the Lithuanian Army
         <a href="/wiki/Stasys_Ra%C5%A1tikis" title="Stasys Raštikis">
          Stasys Raštikis
         </a>
         personally visited the Nazi Generals trying to plead the Jews
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the occupation, the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Diplomatic_Service" title="Lithuanian Diplomatic Service">
        Lithuanian Diplomatic Service
       </a>
       did not recognized the new occupants authority and started the diplomatic liberation campaign of Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LRS1940_93-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LRS1940-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1941,
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_%C5%A0kirpa" title="Kazys Škirpa">
        Kazys Škirpa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Leonas_Prapuolenis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Leonas Prapuolenis (page does not exist)">
        Leonas Prapuolenis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Ambrazevi%C4%8Dius" title="Juozas Ambrazevičius">
        Juozas Ambrazevičius
       </a>
       and their supporters, including the former Commander of the Lithuanian Army General
       <a href="/wiki/Stasys_Ra%C5%A1tikis" title="Stasys Raštikis">
        Stasys Raštikis
       </a>
       , whose whole family was deported to
       <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">
        Siberia
       </a>
       , began organizing an uprising.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rastikis_92-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rastikis-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After realizing the repressive and brutal Soviet rule reality, in early morning of 22 June 1941 (the first day when the
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">
        Nazi Germany
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">
        attacked the Soviet Union
       </a>
       ) Lithuanians began the
       <a href="/wiki/June_Uprising_in_Lithuania" title="June Uprising in Lithuania">
        June Uprising
       </a>
       , organized by the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Activist_Front" title="Lithuanian Activist Front">
        Lithuanian Activist Front
       </a>
       , in
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       where its main forces were concentrated. The uprising soon expanded to
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       and other locations. Its main goal was not to fight with the Soviets, but to secure the city from inside (secure organizations, institutions, enterprises) and declare independence. By the evening of June 22, the Lithuanians controlled the
       <a href="/wiki/Historical_Presidential_Palace,_Kaunas" title="Historical Presidential Palace, Kaunas">
        Presidential Palace
       </a>
       , post office, telephone and telegraph, radio station and radiophone. The control of Vilnius and most of the Lithuania's territory was also shortly taken by the rebels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LLKS_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LLKS-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Multiple Red Army divisions stationed in the Lithuania's territory, including the brutal
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1st_Motor_Rifle_Division_NKVD" title="1st Motor Rifle Division NKVD">
        1st Motor Rifle Division NKVD
       </a>
       responsible for the
       <a href="/wiki/June_deportation" title="June deportation">
        June deportation
       </a>
       , and the marionette
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Lithuanian SSR
       </a>
       regime commanders were forced to flee into the
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Latvian SSR
       </a>
       through the
       <a href="/wiki/Daugava" title="Daugava">
        Daugava
       </a>
       river. Commander of the Red Army's 188th Rifle Division colonel Piotr Ivanov reported to the 11th Army Staff that during the retreat of his division through Kaunas "local counterrevolutionaries from the shelters purposefully and severely fired to the Red Army, the flocks suffered heavy losses of soldiers and military equipment".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 5,000 occupants were killed in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 23 June 1941 at 9:28 AM
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Tauti%C5%A1ka_giesm%C4%97" title="Tautiška giesmė">
         Tautiška giesmė
        </a>
       </i>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">
        national anthem
       </a>
       of Lithuania, was played on the radio in Kaunas. Many people listened to the Lithuanian national anthem then with tears in their eyes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From Kaunas radio broadcasts, Lithuania learned that the rebellion was taking place in the country, the insurgents took Kaunas, the Proclamation of the Independence Restoration of Lithuania and the list of the
       <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Lithuania" title="Provisional Government of Lithuania">
        Provisional Government of Lithuania
       </a>
       was announced.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LLKS_95-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LLKS-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2503" data-file-width="4546" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG/220px-Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG/330px-Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG/440px-Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaunas_KZ_IX._Fort_Memorial_09.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Memorial for the victims of the
         <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
          World War II
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
          Kaunas
         </a>
         . Lithuania lost over 1 million citizens (one third) during the war and the first post-war decade under the
         <a href="/wiki/Political_repression_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Political repression in the Soviet Union">
          repressive Soviet regime
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
          <a href="#cite_note-100">
           [100]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Provisional Government hoped that the Germans would re-establish Lithuania independence or at least allow some degree of autonomy (similar to the
       <a href="/wiki/Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="Slovak Republic (1939–1945)">
        Slovak Republic
       </a>
       ), was seeking for the protection of the citizens and did not supported the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nazis" title="Nazis">
        Nazis
       </a>
       '
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">
        Holocaust
       </a>
       policy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LLKS_95-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-LLKS-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The meant Lithuanian Minister of National Defence Stasys Raštikis personally met with the Nazi Generals to discuss the situation and tried to plead the Jews, while the Provisional Government, together with the former President
       <a href="/wiki/Kazys_Grinius" title="Kazys Grinius">
        Kazys Grinius
       </a>
       , condemned Nazis for their actions with Jews already in the beginning of the occupation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although, on July 17 the
       <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ostland" title="Reichskommissariat Ostland">
        Reichskommissariat Ostland
       </a>
       , German Civil Administration (
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zivilverwaltung" title="Zivilverwaltung">
         Zivilverwaltung
        </a>
       </i>
       ) was established.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Instead of using brute force, the Civil Administration slowly removed the government's powers (for example, did not allow to print its decrees in newspapers or broadcast radio announcements) and supplanted its institutions, forcing the Provisional Government to either self-disband or to become a puppet institution.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mi47_103-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mi47-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government self-disbanded on August 5 after signing a protest for the Germans actions of suspending the Lithuanian Government powers. Members of the Provisional Government then
       <i>
        in corpore
       </i>
       went to the Garden of the
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great_War_Museum" title="Vytautas the Great War Museum">
        Vytautas the Great War Museum
       </a>
       , where they laid wreath near the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the presence of a numerous audience.
       <a href="/wiki/Sicherheitsdienst" title="Sicherheitsdienst">
        Sicherheitsdienst
       </a>
       confiscated the pictures of the wreath-laying ceremony, thinking that it could be dangerous for the
       <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Lithuania_during_World_War_II" title="German occupation of Lithuania during World War II">
        German occupation policy in Lithuania
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A new occupation had begun. Nationalized assets were not returned to the residents. Some of them were forced to fight for Nazi Germany or were taken to German territories as a forced laborers.
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jewish
       </a>
       people were herded into ghettos and gradually killed by shooting or sending them out to concentration camps.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="1944.E2.80.931991">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="1944–1991">
        1944–1991
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:N._Vilnia,_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG/220px-N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG/330px-N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG/440px-N._Vilnia%2C_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:N._Vilnia,_paminklas_tremtiniams.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Monument in
         <a href="/wiki/Naujoji_Vilnia" title="Naujoji Vilnia">
          Naujoji Vilnia
         </a>
         in memory of the ferocious
         <a href="/wiki/Soviet_deportations_from_Lithuania" title="Soviet deportations from Lithuania">
          Soviet deportations from Lithuania
         </a>
         of approx 129,475 people in
         <a href="/wiki/Goods_wagon" title="Goods wagon">
          animals wagons
         </a>
         . Many of them died suffering due to the unbearable living conditions. One tenth of them were children, 5,000 died.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
          <a href="#cite_note-107">
           [107]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the retreat of the
       <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">
        German armed forces
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_and_annexation_of_the_Baltic_states_by_the_Soviet_Union_(1944)" title="Occupation and annexation of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union (1944)">
        Soviets reestablished the annexation of Lithuania
       </a>
       in 1944. Under border changes promulgated at the
       <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">
        Potsdam Conference
       </a>
       of 1945, the former German
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memelland" title="Memelland">
        Memelland
       </a>
       , with its Baltic port
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaipėda">
        Memel
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="lt">
         Klaipėda
        </span>
       </i>
       ), was again transferred to Lithuania, which was now referred to as the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">
        Lithuanian SSR
       </a>
       . Most of Memelland's German residents had fled the area in the final months of World War II.
      </p>
      <p>
       As the front was heading towards west, in July-October 1944 the USSR took over Lithuania again. The
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
        second Soviet occupation
       </a>
       commenced. The
       <a href="/wiki/Deportation" title="Deportation">
        massive deportations
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">
        Siberia
       </a>
       were resumed and lasted until the death of
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">
        Stalin
       </a>
       in 1953. All Lithuanian national symbols were banned. People were persecuted for using them. Under the pretext of Lithuania’s economic recovery, the
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       authorities encouraged the migration of workers and other specialists to Lithuania with intention to further integrate Lithuania into the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        Soviet Union
       </a>
       and develop country’s industry. At the same time, Lithuanians were lured to work in the USSR by promising them all the privileges of settling in a new place.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:348px;max-width:348px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_(Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force)_in_1946.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="967" data-file-width="1574" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg/220px-Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg/330px-Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg/440px-Members_of_the_Lithuanian_partisans_%28Zalgiris_Territorial_Defense_Force%29_in_1946.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HPIM0823.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2576" data-file-width="1920" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/HPIM0823.JPG/120px-HPIM0823.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/HPIM0823.JPG/180px-HPIM0823.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/HPIM0823.JPG/240px-HPIM0823.JPG 2x" width="120"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:">
         Members of the
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_partisans" title="Lithuanian partisans">
          Lithuanian partisans
         </a>
         , decorated with the
         <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Lithuania" title="National symbols of Lithuania">
          national symbols of Lithuania
         </a>
         and the independent state
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Armed_Forces" title="Lithuanian Armed Forces">
          army
         </a>
         uniforms, persistently fought with the
         <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">
          occupants
         </a>
         . President
         <a href="/wiki/Jonas_%C5%BDemaitis" title="Jonas Žemaitis">
          Jonas Žemaitis
         </a>
         was the Chairman of the
         <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lithuanian_Freedom_Fighters" title="Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters">
          Freedom Fighters
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The second Soviet occupation was accompanied by the armed
       <a href="/wiki/Resistance_in_Lithuania_during_World_War_II" title="Resistance in Lithuania during World War II">
        resistance
       </a>
       of the Lithuanian population, which took place in 1944-1953. It sought to restore an independent state of Lithuania, to consolidate democracy by destroying communism in the country, returning national values and the freedom of religion. People from all walks of life, different age groups and education joined the resistance. The government classified them as bandits. The Soviet occupation made them to go to the forests and fight against the new system with a gun in their hands.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuanian partisan warfare is divided into three stages. The first stage started in summer 1944 and lasted until summer 1946. During this time, large partisan groups were created, but they lacked one unified organization. There were frequent military encounters with the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       . The second stage covered summer 1946 until the end of 1948. At that time, the organizational structure of the partisans was formed, and the size of the groups was reduced to 5-15 people living in bunkers. Partisans used the tactics of underground combat and organized unexpected attacks. The third stage lasted from 1949 to the end of 1953. At that time, the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lithuanian_Freedom_Fighters" title="Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters">
        Union of Lithuanian Freedom Fighters
       </a>
       was founded under the leadership of
       <a href="/wiki/Jonas_%C5%BDemaitis" title="Jonas Žemaitis">
        Jonas Žemaitis
       </a>
       (codename Vytautas). The number of people in a group fell to 3–5 people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Open encounters with the Red Army took place rarely; the guerillas used mostly sabotage and terror. Despite the fact that the guerrilla warfare did not achieve its goal of liberating Lithuania and that it resulted in more than 20 000 deaths, the armed resistance showed the world that Lithuania did not voluntarily join the USSR and it also legitimized the will of the people of Lithuania to be independent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-küng1999_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-küng1999-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Even with the suppression of partisan resistance, the Soviet government failed to stop the movement for the independence of Lithuania. The underground dissident groups were active publishing the underground press and Catholic literature. The most active participants of the movement had been
       <a href="/wiki/Vincentas_Sladkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Vincentas Sladkevičius">
        Vincentas Sladkevičius
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sigitas_Tamkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Sigitas Tamkevičius">
        Sigitas Tamkevičius
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nijol%C4%97_Sad%C5%ABnait%C4%97" title="Nijolė Sadūnaitė">
        Nijolė Sadūnaitė
       </a>
       . In 1972, after
       <a href="/wiki/Romas_Kalanta" title="Romas Kalanta">
        Romas Kalanta’s
       </a>
       public self-immolation, the unrest in
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       lasted for several days.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2624" data-file-width="3936" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/220px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/330px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg/440px-Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baltsk%C3%BD%C5%98et%C4%9Bz.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">
          Baltic Way
         </a>
         , the human chain connecting the three Baltic capitals
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Helsinki_Group" title="Lithuanian Helsinki Group">
        Helsinki Group
       </a>
       , which was founded in Lithuania after the international conference in Helsinki (Finland), where the post-WWII borders were acknowledged, announced a declaration for Lithuania’s independence on foreign radio station.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The dissident movement lifted up the spirit of the people and did not allow forgetting history and national values. The Helsinki Group informed the Western world about the situation in the Soviet Lithuania and violations of human rights. All these activities made
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       to soften its grip. With the beginning of the increased openness and transparency in government institutions and activities (
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">
         glasnost
        </a>
       </i>
       ) in the Soviet Union, on June 3 1988, the
       <a href="/wiki/S%C4%85j%C5%ABdis" title="Sąjūdis">
        Sąjūdis
       </a>
       was established in Lithuania. Very soon it began to seek country's independence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Landsbergis" title="Vytautas Landsbergis">
        Vytautas Landsbergis
       </a>
       became movement's leader.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The supporters of Sąjūdis joined movement's groups all over Lithuania. On 23 August 1988 a big rally took place at the
       <a href="/wiki/Vingis_Park" title="Vingis Park">
        Vingis Park
       </a>
       in Vilnius. It was attended by approx. 250 000 people. A year later, on 23 August 1989 celebrating the 50th anniversary of the
       <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">
        Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact
       </a>
       and aiming to draw the attention of the whole world to the occupation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic States
       </a>
       , a political demonstration, the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">
        Baltic Way
       </a>
       , was organized.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The event, led by
       <a href="/wiki/S%C4%85j%C5%ABdis" title="Sąjūdis">
        Sąjūdis
       </a>
       , was a human chain spanning about 600 kilometers across the three Baltic capitals—
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">
        Riga
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       . The peaceful demonstration showed the desire of the people of Lithuania,
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">
        Estonia
       </a>
       to break away from the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        USSR
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:348px;max-width:348px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_(2).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="780" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/220px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/330px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg/440px-Seimas_Palace_during_January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1136" data-file-width="800" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/120px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/180px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png/240px-Act_of_Restoration_of_Independence_of_Lithuania_1990-03-11.png 2x" width="120"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:">
         On 11 March 1990, the
         <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council – Reconstituent Seimas">
          Supreme Council
         </a>
         announced the
         <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania" title="Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania">
          restoration of Lithuania's independence
         </a>
         . After refusal to revocate the Act, the
         <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">
          Soviet forces
         </a>
         stormed the
         <a href="/wiki/Seimas_Palace" title="Seimas Palace">
          Seimas Palace
         </a>
         , while Lithuanians irresistibly defended their
         <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
          democratically
         </a>
         elected Council. The Act was the first such declaration in the USSR and later served as a model, inspiration to other
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_republics" title="Soviet republics">
          Soviet republics
         </a>
         , and strongly influenced the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_USSR" title="Dissolution of the USSR">
          dissolution of the USSR
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On 11 March 1990, the
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council – Reconstituent Seimas">
        Supreme Council
       </a>
       announced the restoration of Lithuania's independence. Lithuania became the first
       <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">
        Soviet republic
       </a>
       to announce its secession from the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
        USSR
       </a>
       . But the process was not so simple. On 20 April 1990, the USSR imposed an
       <a href="/wiki/Blockade" title="Blockade">
        economic blockade
       </a>
       by stopping to deliver supplies of raw materials (primarily oil) to Lithuania. Not only the domestic industry, but also the population started feeling the lack of fuel, essential goods, and even hot water. Although, the blockade lasted for 74 days, Lithuania did not renounce the declaration of independence.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="514" data-file-width="800" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/220px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/330px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg/440px-January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:January_13_events_in_Vilnius_Lithuania.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         On
         <a href="/wiki/January_Events_(Lithuania)" title="January Events (Lithuania)">
          13 January 1991
         </a>
         , Soviets began shooting and crushing with tanks unarmed independence supporters
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Gradually, the economic relations had been restored. But the tension had peaked again in January 1991. At that time, attempts were made to carry out a coup using the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Armed_Forces" title="Soviet Armed Forces">
        Soviet Armed Forces
       </a>
       , the Internal Army of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the USSR Committee for State Security (
       <a href="/wiki/KGB" title="KGB">
        KGB
       </a>
       ). Because of the bad economic situation in Lithuania, the forces in Moscow thought the
       <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">
        coup d’état
       </a>
       will receive a strong public support. But the situation was the opposite.
      </p>
      <p>
       People from all over Lithuania flooded to
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       to defend their legitimately elected
       <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_%E2%80%93_Reconstituent_Seimas" title="Supreme Council – Reconstituent Seimas">
        Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania
       </a>
       and independence. The coup ended with a few casualties of peaceful civilians and caused huge material loss. Not a single person who defended
       <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
        Lithuanian Parliament
       </a>
       or other state institutions used a weapon, but the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">
        Soviet Army
       </a>
       did. Soviet soldiers killed 14 people and injured hundreds. A large part of the Lithuanian population participated in the January Events.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_115-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bbc-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Shortly after, on February 1991
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       became the first country to recognize the independence of Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 31 July 1991, Soviet paramilitaries killed seven Lithuanian border guards on the Belarusian border in what became known as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medininkai_Massacre" title="Medininkai Massacre">
        Medininkai Massacre
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 17 September 1991, Lithuania was admitted to the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       On 25 October 1992, the citizens of Lithuania voted in the referendum to adopt the current
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">
        constitution
       </a>
       . On 14 February 1993, during the direct general elections,
       <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Brazauskas" title="Algirdas Brazauskas">
        Algirdas Brazauskas
       </a>
       became the first president after the restoration of independence of Lithuania. On 31 August 1993, the last units of the Soviet Army left the territory of Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 29 March 2004, Lithuania has been part of the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       . On 1 May 2004, it became a full-fledged member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , and a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">
        Schengen Agreement
       </a>
       on 21 December 2007.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Lithuania" title="Geography of Lithuania">
        Geography of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/220px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/330px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg/440px-Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Centre_of_Europe.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Geographic Centre of Europe is in Lithuania
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania is located in
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">
        northern
       </a>
       -
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">
        eastern Europe
       </a>
       <sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_NoteA">
        <a href="#endnote_NoteA">
         Note
        </a>
       </sup>
       and covers an area of 65,200 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (25,200 sq mi).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It lies between latitudes
       <a href="/wiki/53rd_parallel_north" title="53rd parallel north">
        53°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/57th_parallel_north" title="57th parallel north">
        57° N
       </a>
       , and mostly between longitudes
       <a href="/wiki/21st_meridian_east" title="21st meridian east">
        21°
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/27th_meridian_east" title="27th meridian east">
        27° E
       </a>
       (part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Spit" title="Curonian Spit">
        Curonian Spit
       </a>
       lies west of 21°). It has around 99 kilometres (61.5 mi) of sandy coastline, only about 38 kilometres (24 mi) of which face the open
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">
        Baltic Sea
       </a>
       , less than the other two
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea_countries" title="Baltic Sea countries">
        Baltic Sea countries
       </a>
       . The rest of the coast is sheltered by the Curonian sand peninsula. Lithuania's major
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warm-water_port" title="Warm-water port">
        warm-water port
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaipėda">
        Klaipėda
       </a>
       , lies at the narrow mouth of the
       <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Lagoon" title="Curonian Lagoon">
        Curonian Lagoon
       </a>
       (Lithuanian:
       <i>
        Kuršių marios
       </i>
       ), a shallow lagoon extending south to
       <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad" title="Kaliningrad">
        Kaliningrad
       </a>
       . The country's main and largest river, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nemunas_River" title="Nemunas River">
        Nemunas River
       </a>
       , and some of its tributaries carry international shipping.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:227px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Memel_R..JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="966" data-file-width="1288" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Memel_R..JPG/225px-Memel_R..JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Memel_R..JPG/338px-Memel_R..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Memel_R..JPG/450px-Memel_R..JPG 2x" width="225"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Memel_R..JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Nemunas (Nieman) River between Lithuania and Russia's
         <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">
          Kaliningrad Oblast
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania lies at the edge of the
       <a href="/wiki/North_European_Plain" title="North European Plain">
        North European Plain
       </a>
       . Its landscape was smoothed by the glaciers of the
       <a href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">
        last ice age
       </a>
       , and is a combination of moderate lowlands and highlands. Its highest point is
       <a href="/wiki/Auk%C5%A1tojas_Hill" title="Aukštojas Hill">
        Aukštojas Hill
       </a>
       at 294 metres (965 ft) in the eastern part of the country. The terrain features
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_in_Lithuania" title="List of lakes in Lithuania">
        numerous lakes
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Vi%C5%A1tytis" title="Lake Vištytis">
        Lake Vištytis
       </a>
       , for example) and wetlands, and a mixed forest zone covers over 33% of the country.
      </p>
      <p>
       After a re-estimation of the boundaries of the
       <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">
        continent
       </a>
       of Europe in 1989, Jean-George Affholder, a scientist at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Institut_g%C3%A9ographique_national_(France)" title="Institut géographique national (France)">
        Institut Géographique National
       </a>
       (French National Geographic Institute), determined that the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geographic_centre_of_Europe" title="Geographic centre of Europe">
        geographic centre of Europe
       </a>
       was in Lithuania, at
       <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion">
        <a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Lithuania&amp;params=54_54_N_25_19_E_type:landmark&amp;title=Purnu%C5%A1k%C4%97s+%28centre+of+gravity%29">
         <span class="geo-default">
