          <span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
           <span class="latitude">
            54°54′N
           </span>
           <span class="longitude">
            25°19′E
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
         <span class="geo-multi-punct">
          ﻿ / ﻿
         </span>
         <span class="geo-nondefault">
          <span class="vcard">
           <span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">
            54.900°N 25.317°E
           </span>
           <span style="display:none">
            ﻿ /
            <span class="geo">
             54.900; 25.317
            </span>
           </span>
           <span style="display:none">
            ﻿ (
            <span class="fn org">
             Purnuškės (centre of gravity)
            </span>
            )
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </a>
       </span>
       , 26 kilometres (16 mi) north of Lithuania's capital city of
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Affholder accomplished this by calculating the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_of_gravity" title="Centre of gravity">
        centre of gravity
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Europe" title="Geography of Europe">
        geometrical figure
       </a>
       of Europe.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Lithuania#Climate" title="Geography of Lithuania">
        Geography of Lithuania § Climate
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg/220px-Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg/330px-Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg/440px-Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_Ladakalnis.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Auk%C5%A1taitija_National_Park" title="Aukštaitija National Park">
          Aukštaitija National Park
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nida_sand_dunes_(14573723178).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2315" data-file-width="4928" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/220px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/330px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg/440px-Nida_sand_dunes_%2814573723178%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nida_sand_dunes_(14573723178).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Sand dunes of the
         <a href="/wiki/Curonian_Spit" title="Curonian Spit">
          Curonian Spit
         </a>
         near
         <a href="/wiki/Nida,_Lithuania" title="Nida, Lithuania">
          Nida
         </a>
         , which are the highest drifting sand dunes in Europe (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
          UNESCO World Heritage Site
         </a>
         )
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
          <a href="#cite_note-121">
           [121]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania's climate, which ranges between
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">
        maritime
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        continental
       </a>
       , is relatively mild. Average temperatures on the coast are −2.5 °C (27.5 °F) in January and 16 °C (61 °F) in July. In Vilnius the average temperatures are −6 °C (21 °F) in January and 17 °C (63 °F) in July. During the summer, 20 °C (68 °F) is common during the day while 14 °C (57 °F) is common at night; in the past, temperatures have reached as high as 30 or 35 °C (86 or 95 °F). Some winters can be very cold. −20 °C (−4 °F) occurs almost every winter. Winter extremes are −34 °C (−29 °F) in coastal areas and −43 °C (−45 °F) in the east of Lithuania.
      </p>
      <p>
       The average annual precipitation is 800 mm (31.5 in) on the coast, 900 mm (35.4 in) in the Samogitia highlands and 600 mm (23.6 in) in the eastern part of the country. Snow occurs every year, it can snow from October to April. In some years sleet can fall in September or May. The growing season lasts 202 days in the western part of the country and 169 days in the eastern part. Severe storms are rare in the eastern part of Lithuania but common in the coastal areas.
      </p>
      <p>
       The longest records of measured temperature in the Baltic area cover about 250 years. The data show warm periods during the latter half of the 18th century, and that the 19th century was a relatively cool period. An early 20th century warming culminated in the 1930s, followed by a smaller cooling that lasted until the 1960s. A warming trend has persisted since then.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania experienced a drought in 2002, causing forest and
       <a href="/wiki/Peat" title="Peat">
        peat
       </a>
       bog fires.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country suffered along with the rest of Northwestern Europe during a heat wave in the summer of 2006.
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <table class="wikitable" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">

      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:846px;max-width:846px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sakuras_in_Vilnius_(2016_spring).jpg">

          </a>

         <center>
          Lithuania has all four
          <a href="/wiki/Season" title="Season">
           seasons
          </a>
          of the year with hot summers and cold winters
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Lithuania" title="Politics of Lithuania">
        Politics of Lithuania
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Lithuania" title="Elections in Lithuania">
        Elections in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:right; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg">
          <img alt="Dalia Grybauskaitė.jpg" data-file-height="395" data-file-width="280" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/125px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/188px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg/250px-Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97.jpg 2x" width="125"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg">
          <img alt="Saulius Skvernelis.jpg" data-file-height="896" data-file-width="659" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/131px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/197px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg/262px-Saulius_Skvernelis.jpg 2x" width="131"/>
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskaitė">
          Dalia Grybauskaitė
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">
           President
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Saulius_Skvernelis" title="Saulius Skvernelis">
          Saulius Skvernelis
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania" title="Prime Minister of Lithuania">
           Prime Minister
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Since Lithuania declared the restoration of its independence on 11 March 1990, it has maintained strong democratic traditions. It held its first independent general elections on 25 October 1992, in which 56.75% of voters supported the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">
        new constitution
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referenda_127-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-referenda-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There were intense debates concerning the constitution, particularly the role of the president. A
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidency_referendum,_1992" title="Lithuanian presidency referendum, 1992">
        separate referendum
       </a>
       was held on 23 May 1992 to gauge public opinion on the matter, and 41% of voters supported the restoration of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/President_of_Lithuania" title="President of Lithuania">
        President of Lithuania
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-referenda_127-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-referenda-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Through compromise, a
       <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">
        semi-presidential system
       </a>
       was agreed on.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lina_2-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lina-2">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Lithuanian
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       is the president, directly elected for a five-year term and serving a maximum of two terms. The president oversees foreign affairs and national security, and is the
       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">
        commander-in-chief
       </a>
       of the military. The president also appoints the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania" title="Prime Minister of Lithuania">
        prime minister
       </a>
       and, on the latter's nomination, the rest of the cabinet, as well as a number of other top civil servants and the judges for all courts.
      </p>
      <p>
       The current Lithuanian head of state,
       <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskaitė">
        Dalia Grybauskaitė
       </a>
       was
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidential_election,_2009" title="Lithuanian presidential election, 2009">
        elected on 17 May 2009
       </a>
       , becoming the first female president in the country's history, and the second female head of state in the Baltic States after
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       elected their first female political leader in 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Dalia Grybauskaitė was
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_presidential_election,_2014" title="Lithuanian presidential election, 2014">
        re-elected for a second term in 2014
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The judges of the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Lithuania" title="Constitutional Court of Lithuania">
        Constitutional Court
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Konstitucinis Teismas
       </i>
       ) serve nine-year terms. They are appointed by the President, the Chairman of the Seimas, and the Chairman of the Supreme Court, each of whom appoint three judges. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">
        unicameral
       </a>
       Lithuanian parliament, the
       <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
        Seimas
       </a>
       , has 141 members who are elected to four-year terms. 71 of the members of its members are elected in single member constituencies, and the others in a nationwide vote by
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       . A party must receive at least 5% of the national vote to be eligible for any of the 70 national seats in the Seimas.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/220px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/330px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg/440px-Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seimas_litauensparlament.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Seimas" title="Seimas">
          Seimas
         </a>
         — (Parliament of Lithuania)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>

         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:144px; top:342px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">
          <span style="color: grey;">
           Poland
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
       <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:242px">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
          <span style="color: grey;">
           Russia
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The current system of administrative division was established in 1994 and modified in 2000 to meet the requirements of the European Union. The country's
       <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Lithuania" title="Counties of Lithuania">
        10 counties
       </a>
       (Lithuanian: singular –
       <i>
        apskritis
       </i>
       , plural –
       <i>
        apskritys
       </i>
       ) are subdivided into
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Lithuania" title="Municipalities of Lithuania">
        60 municipalities
       </a>
       (Lithuanian: singular –
       <i>
        savivaldybė
       </i>
       , plural –
       <i>
        savivaldybės
       </i>
       ), and further divided into 500
       <a href="/wiki/Elderships_of_Lithuania" title="Elderships of Lithuania">
        elderships
       </a>
       (Lithuanian: singular –
       <i>
        seniūnija
       </i>
       , plural –
       <i>
        seniūnijos
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Municipalities have been the most important unit of administration in Lithuania since the system of
       <a href="/wiki/County_governor_(Lithuania)" title="County governor (Lithuania)">
        county governorship
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        apskrities viršininkas
       </i>
       ) was dissolved in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-county_129-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-county-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some municipalities are historically called "district municipalities" (often shortened to "district"), while others are called "city municipalities" (sometimes shortened to "city"). Each has its own elected government. The election of municipality councils originally occurred every three years, but now takes place every four years. The council appoints
       <a href="/wiki/Elder_(administrative_title)" title="Elder (administrative title)">
        elders
       </a>
       to govern the elderships. Mayors have been directly elected since 2015; prior to that, they were appointed by the council.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Elderships, numbering over 500, are the smallest administrative units and do not play a role in national politics. They provide necessary local public services—for example, registering births and deaths in rural areas. They are most active in the social sector, identifying needy individuals or families and organizing and distributing welfare and other forms of relief.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-elderates_131-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-elderates-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some citizens feel that elderships have no real power and receive too little attention, and that they could otherwise become a source of local initiative for addressing rural problems.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%;">
       <tr style="font-size:100%; text-align:right;">
        <th style="width:140px;">

      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Lithuania" title="Foreign relations of Lithuania">
        Foreign relations of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1959" data-file-width="2942" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/220px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/330px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg/440px-Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Institutions_europeennes_IMG_4300.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuania is a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_State_of_the_European_Union" title="Member State of the European Union">
          member of the European Union
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania became a member of the United Nations on 18 September 1991, and is a signatory to a number of its organizations and other international agreements. It is also a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">
        Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
       </a>
       , as well as
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       and its adjunct North Atlantic Coordinating Council. Lithuania gained membership in the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        World Trade Organization
       </a>
       on 31 May 2001, and currently seeks membership in the OECD and other Western organizations.
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania has established diplomatic relations with 149 countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2011, Lithuania hosted the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
        Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
       </a>
       Ministerial Council Meeting. During the second half of 2013, Lithuania assumed the role of the
       <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">
        presidency of the European Union
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="614" data-file-width="858" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/220px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/330px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/440px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The stamp is dedicated to Lithuania's presidency of the European Union. Post of Lithuania, 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania is also active in developing cooperation among northern European countries. It has been a member of the Baltic Council since its establishment in 1993. The Baltic Council, located in
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       , is a permanent organisation of international cooperation that operates through the
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">
        Baltic Assembly
       </a>
       and the Baltic Council of Ministers.
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania also cooperates with Nordic and the two other Baltic countries through the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NB8" title="NB8">
        NB8
       </a>
       format. A similar format, NB6, unites Nordic and Baltic members of EU. NB6's focus is to discuss and agree on positions before presenting them to the Council of the European Union and at the meetings of EU foreign affairs ministers.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Baltic_Sea_States" title="Council of the Baltic Sea States">
        Council of the Baltic Sea States
       </a>
       (CBSS) was established in
       <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">
        Copenhagen
       </a>
       in 1992 as an informal regional political forum. Its main aim is to promote integration and to close contacts between the region's countries. The members of CBSS are Iceland, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Germany, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Poland, Russia, and the European Commission. Its observer states are Belarus, France, Italy, Netherlands, Romania, Slovakia, Spain, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Ukraine.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council" title="Nordic Council">
        Nordic Council of Ministers
       </a>
       and Lithuania engage in political cooperation to attain mutual goals and to determine new trends and possibilities for joint cooperation. The Council's information office aims to disseminate
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">
        Nordic
       </a>
       concepts and to demonstrate and promote Nordic cooperation.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2333" data-file-width="3500" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_chairs_a_United_Nations_Security_Council_meeting.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuania was recently a member of the
         <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
          United Nations Security Council
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania, together with the five Nordic countries and the two other Baltic countries, is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Investment_Bank" title="Nordic Investment Bank">
        Nordic Investment Bank (NIB)
       </a>
       and cooperates in its NORDPLUS programme, which is committed to education.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Baltic Development Forum (BDF) is an independent nonprofit organization that unites large companies, cities, business associations and institutions in the Baltic Sea region. In 2010 the BDF's 12th summit was held in Vilnius.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania maintains greatly warm mutual relations with
       <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">
        Georgia
       </a>
       and strongly supports its European Union and NATO aspirations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War" title="Russo-Georgian War">
        Russo-Georgian War
       </a>
       in 2008, when the Russian troops were occupying the territory of Georgia and approaching towards the Georgian capital
       <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">
        Tbilisi
       </a>
       , President
       <a href="/wiki/Valdas_Adamkus" title="Valdas Adamkus">
        Valdas Adamkus
       </a>
       , together with the Polish and Ukrainian presidents, went to Tbilisi by answering to the Georgians request of the international assistance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Shortly, Lithuanians and the
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Lithuania" title="Catholic Church in Lithuania">
        Lithuanian Catholic Church
       </a>
       also began collecting financial support for the war victims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013, Lithuania was elected to the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
        United Nations Security Council
       </a>
       for a two-year term,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       becoming the first
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic
       </a>
       country elected to this post. During its membership, Lithuania actively supported
       <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">
        Ukraine
       </a>
       and often condemned
       <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
        Russia
       </a>
       for the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)">
        military intervention in Ukraine
       </a>
       , immediately earning vast Ukrainians esteem.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As the
       <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">
        War in Donbass
       </a>
       progressed, President
       <a href="/wiki/Dalia_Grybauskait%C4%97" title="Dalia Grybauskaitė">
        Dalia Grybauskaitė
       </a>
       has compared the Russian President
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">
        Vladimir Putin
       </a>
       to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Josef_Stalin" title="Josef Stalin">
        Josef Stalin
       </a>
       and to
       <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">
        Adolf Hitler
       </a>
       , she has also called Russia a “terrorist state”.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Armed_Forces" title="Lithuanian Armed Forces">
        Lithuanian Armed Forces
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="533" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg/170px-LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg/255px-LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg/340px-LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LT_KASP_mokymai.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Soldier of the
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Defence_Volunteer_Forces" title="Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces">
          Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Lithuanian Armed Forces is the name for the unified armed forces of
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Land_Force" title="Lithuanian Land Force">
        Lithuanian Land Force
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Air_Force" title="Lithuanian Air Force">
        Lithuanian Air Force
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Naval_Force" title="Lithuanian Naval Force">
        Lithuanian Naval Force
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Special_Operations_Force" title="Lithuanian Special Operations Force">
        Lithuanian Special Operations Force
       </a>
       and other units: Logistics Command, Training and Doctrine Command, Headquarters Battalion,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Lithuania)" title="Military Police (Lithuania)">
        Military Police
       </a>
       . Directly subordinated to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_of_Defence" title="Chief of Defence">
        Chief of Defence
       </a>
       are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Operations_Forces" title="Special Operations Forces">
        Special Operations Forces
       </a>
       and Military Police. The Reserve Forces are under command of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Defence_Volunteer_Forces" title="Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces">
        Lithuanian National Defence Volunteer Forces
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="518" data-file-width="779" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg/220px-LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg/330px-LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg/440px-LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LT_KASP_PAG4.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuanian soldiers on the international
         <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
          NATO
         </a>
         mission in
         <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
          Afghanistan
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_(8123251773).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2241" data-file-width="3456" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/330px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg/440px-Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_%288123251773%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuanian_army_in_Vilnius_(8123251773).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuanian Army soldiers marching with their
         <a href="/wiki/Dress_uniform" title="Dress uniform">
          dress uniforms
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
          Vilnius
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Lithuanian Armed Forces consist of some 15,000 active personnel, which may be supported by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reserve_forces" title="Reserve forces">
        reserve forces
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Compulsory
       <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">
        conscription
       </a>
       ended in 2008 but was reintroduced in 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Lithuanian Armed Forces currently have deployed personnel on international missions in Afghanistan, Kosovo, Mali and Somalia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In March 2004, Lithuania became a full member of the
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       . Since then,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fighter_jets" title="Fighter jets">
        fighter jets
       </a>
       of NATO members are deployed in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zokniai_airport" title="Zokniai airport">
        Zokniai airport
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Air_Policing" title="Baltic Air Policing">
        provide safety for the Baltic airspace
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the summer of 2005 Lithuania has been part of the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">
        International Security Assistance Force
       </a>
       in Afghanistan (ISAF), leading a
       <a href="/wiki/Provincial_Reconstruction_Team" title="Provincial Reconstruction Team">
        Provincial Reconstruction Team
       </a>
       (PRT) in the town of
       <a href="/wiki/Chaghcharan" title="Chaghcharan">
        Chaghcharan
       </a>
       in the province of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghor" title="Ghor">
        Ghor
       </a>
       . The PRT includes personnel from
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       , Iceland and USA. There are also
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Special_Operations_Force" title="Lithuanian Special Operations Force">
        special operation forces
       </a>
       units in Afghanistan, placed in
       <a href="/wiki/Kandahar_Province" title="Kandahar Province">
        Kandahar Province
       </a>
       . Since joining international operations in 1994, Lithuania has lost two soldiers: 1st Lt. Normundas Valteris fell in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosnia" title="Bosnia">
        Bosnia
       </a>
       , as his patrol vehicle drove over a mine. Sgt. Arūnas Jarmalavičius was fatally wounded during an attack on the camp of his Provincial Reconstruction Team in
       <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
        Afghanistan
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Lithuanian National Defence Policy aims to guarantee the preservation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">
        independence
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">
        sovereignty
       </a>
       of the state, the
       <a href="/wiki/Integrity" title="Integrity">
        integrity
       </a>
       of its land, territorial waters and airspace, and its constitutional order. Its main strategic goals are to defend the country's interests, and to maintain and expand the capabilities of its armed forces so they may contribute to and participate in the missions of NATO and European Union member states.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WB_151-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WB-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_of_the_Republic_of_Lithuania" title="Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Lithuania">
        defense ministry
       </a>
       is responsible for combat forces,
       <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue" title="Search and rescue">
        search and rescue
       </a>
       , and intelligence operations. The 5,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_Border_Guard_Service_(Lithuania)" title="State Border Guard Service (Lithuania)">
        border guards
       </a>
       fall under the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interior_Ministry" title="Interior Ministry">
        Interior Ministry
       </a>
       's supervision and are responsible for border protection, passport and customs duties, and share responsibility with the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Naval_Force" title="Lithuanian Naval Force">
        navy
       </a>
       for
       <a href="/wiki/Smuggling" title="Smuggling">
        smuggling
       </a>
       and drug trafficking interdiction. A special security department handles VIP protection and
       <a href="/wiki/Communications_security" title="Communications security">
        communications security
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       According to NATO, in 2017 Lithuania allocated 1.77% of its
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        GDP
       </a>
       to the national defense. For a long time Lithuania lagged behind NATO allies in terms of defense spending, but in recent years it has begun to rapidly increase the funding. In 2018 Lithuania intends to allocate 2.06% of its
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        GDP
       </a>
       to the defense sector and reach the required funding standard for NATO.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Lithuania" title="Economy of Lithuania">
        Economy of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Lithuania" title="Corruption in Lithuania">
        Corruption in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GNI_per_capita(Lithuania).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3095" data-file-width="6300" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg/220px-GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg/330px-GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg/440px-GNI_per_capita%28Lithuania%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GNI_per_capita(Lithuania).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         GNI per capita
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
          <a href="#cite_note-153">
           [153]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD,_2015.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3196" data-file-width="4592" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png/220px-Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png/330px-Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png/440px-Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD%2C_2015.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Labour_productivity_levels_in_Europe._OECD,_2015.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_productivity" title="Labour productivity">
          Labour productivity
         </a>
         level of Lithuania is one of the lowest in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EU" title="EU">
          EU
         </a>
         .
         <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
          OECD
         </a>
         , 2015
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
          <a href="#cite_note-154">
           [154]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia,_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="805" data-file-width="1095" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/220px-2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/330px-2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/440px-2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2016_State_Revenues_Per_Capita_for_Estonia,_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Confirmed state budget revenue projections in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EUR" title="EUR">
          EUR
         </a>
         per capita for 2016 in
         <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">
          Estonia
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
          Latvia
         </a>
         and Lithuania.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia,_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="805" data-file-width="1095" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/220px-Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/330px-Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png/440px-Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia%2C_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Average_monthly_gross_salaries_in_Estonia,_Latvia_and_Lithuania.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Average monthly gross salaries in
         <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">
          Estonia
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
          Latvia
         </a>
         and Lithuania. Time period: 2016, 2nd quarter.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_treemap.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="865" data-file-width="1106" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Lithuania_treemap.png/300px-Lithuania_treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Lithuania_treemap.png/450px-Lithuania_treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Lithuania_treemap.png/600px-Lithuania_treemap.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_treemap.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Graphical depiction of Lithuania's product exports in 28 color-coded categories.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to data from 2014, the three largest sectors in Lithuanian economy are – industry (23,6% of GDP), real estate construction (14%) and transportation (12,9%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These three sectors account for more than half of Lithuanian economy. The lion share of Lithuanian industry is concentrated in food manufacturing and manufacturing of wood products, primarily furniture. Wood furniture makes around half of all Lithuanian exports and
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       food products stand for around 25% of all exports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to data from 2015, more than half of all Lithuanian exports go to 6 countries including Russia (13,6%), Latvia (10,0%), Poland (9,7%), Germany (8,2%), Estonia (5,4%) and Belarus (4,9%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuanian GDP experienced very high real growth rates for decade up to 2009, peaking at 11.1% in 2007. As a result, the country was often termed as a
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Tiger" title="Baltic Tiger">
        Baltic Tiger
       </a>
       . However, 2009 marked experienced a drastic decline – GDP contracted by 14.9%
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and unemployment rate reached 17.8% in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the decline of 2009, Lithuanian annual economic growth has been much slower compared to pre-2009 years.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="690" data-file-width="645" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/220px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/330px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/440px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Lithuania is part of a monetary union, the
         <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
          eurozone
         </a>
         (dark blue), and of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" title="Internal Market (European Union)">
          EU single market
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       On average, more than 95% of all
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">
        foreign direct investment
       </a>
       in Lithuania comes from
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       countries. Sweden is historically the largest investor with 20% – 30% of all FDI in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">
        World Economic Forum's
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">
        Global Competitiveness Report
       </a>
       ranks Lithuania 41st (of 137 ranked countries).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most problematic factors for doing business in Lithuania, according to World Bank's assessment are – tax rates and regulations, restrictive regulations, policy instability, inefficient government bureaucracy and inadequately educated workforce.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_164-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-auto-164">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania joined Nato in 2004
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , EU in 2004
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">
        Schengen
       </a>
       in 2007
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       . On Jan 1 of 2015, euro became the national currency replacing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Litas" title="Litas">
        litas
       </a>
       at the rate of EUR 1.00 = LTL 3.45280.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iso4217news2014_168-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-iso4217news2014-168">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the period between 2004 and 2016, one out of five Lithuanians left the country, mostly because of poor financial situation
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , perceived social injustice
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       or better career opportunities abroad.
       <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">
        Mass emigration
       </a>
       from the country had been going on since 1992 – Lithuania's population has been decreasing every year and every quarter since 1992. Record numbers left the country in 2010 and 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Long term mass emigration has resulted in noticeable shortages on the labor market
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and growth in salaries being larger than growth in labor efficiency.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.org_173-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.org-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanian economists predict that ongoing labor shortages will hinder sustained economic growth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.org_173-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.org-173">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2016, Lithuanian median adult wealth was
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USD" title="USD">
        $
       </a>
       10,915.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       One out of five Lithuanian citizens lives below poverty line
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and more than 30% live on the verge of poverty.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 2012, Lithuania is classified as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-income_economy" title="High-income economy">
        high-income economy
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       2000 EUR is considered a very good monthly salary in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Judge" title="Judge">
        Judges
       </a>
       are the highest paid public employees in the country with an average wage of 2389,9 euros, that is six times higher than the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_minimum_wages_by_country" title="List of minimum wages by country">
        minimum wage
       </a>
       of 400 euros.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2017, average gross (pre-tax) salary in Lithuania is 838,7 euros translating to 659 euros net (after tax)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while average pre-tax pension is 288 euros.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 50% of Lithuanian citizens would be unable to cover an unexpected expense of 230 euros.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage" title="List of countries by average wage">
        Average wage
       </a>
       adjusted for
       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">
        purchasing power parity
       </a>
       , is around 1912 USD per month, third lowest in EU.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
        <a href="#cite_note-183">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Although,
       <a href="/wiki/Cost_of_living" title="Cost of living">
        cost of living
       </a>
       in the country also is sufficiently cheap with the
       <a href="/wiki/Household_final_consumption_expenditure" title="Household final consumption expenditure">
        household final consumption expenditure
       </a>
       being more than 2.5 times lower than in
       <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
        Switzerland
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania has a
       <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">
        flat tax
       </a>
       rate rather than a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Graduated_tax" title="Graduated tax">
        progressive scheme
       </a>
       . According to Eurostat,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_186-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu-186">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the personal income tax (15%) and corporate tax (15%) rates in Lithuania are among the lowest in the EU. The country has the lowest implicit rate of tax on capital (9.8%) in the EU. Corporate tax rate in Lithuania is 15% and 5% for small businesses.
      </p>
      <p>
       The country is among moderate innovators group in the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Innovation_Index" title="International Innovation Index">
        International Innovation Index
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">
        Lasers
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">
        biotechnology
       </a>
       are flagship fields of the Lithuanian science and high tech industry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanian "Šviesos konversija" has developed a revolutionary femtosecond laser system that has 80% marketshare worldwide, and is widely used in DNA research, ophthalmological surgeries, nanotech industry and science.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">
        Vilnius University
       </a>
       Laser Research Center has developed one of the most powerful femtosecond lasers in the world dedicated primarily to
       <a href="/wiki/Oncology" title="Oncology">
        oncological diseases
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Vilnius University Biotechnology Institute team led by
       <a href="/wiki/Virginijus_%C5%A0ik%C5%A1nys" title="Virginijus Šikšnys">
        Virginijus Šikšnys
       </a>
       has created
       <a href="/wiki/CRISPR" title="CRISPR">
        CRISPR
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/Cas9" title="Cas9">
        Cas9
       </a>
       DNR "scissors" technology that allows insertion of new genes into the DNA or the correction of DNA errors.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Softneta is famous for developing the medical equipment MedDream that is used by almost 40 countries hospitals in 5 continents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">
        Information technology
       </a>
       production is stably growing in the country every year, reaching 1.9 billion euros in 2016 and is offering in particular rich salaries for the highly qualified employees.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
        Infrastructure
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Communication">
        Communication
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Lithuania" title="Telecommunications in Lithuania">
        Telecommunications in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania has a well developed communications infrastructure. The country has 2,8 million citizens
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 5 million SIM cards.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest mobile network covers 85% of Lithuania's territory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fixed phone network is "adequate" according to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">
        CIA World Factbook
       </a>
       and is in process of being modernised,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but usage of fixed phone lines has been rapidly decreasing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2017, Lithuania was top 30 in the world by average mobile broadband speeds and top 20 by average fixed broadband speeds.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       72% of Lithuanian households have access to internet, a number which in 2017 was among EU's lowest
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in 2016 ranked 97th by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">
        CIA World Factbook
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Number of households with internet access is expected to increase and reach 77% by 2021.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Almost 50% of Lithuanians had smartphones in 2016, a number that is expected to increase to 65% by 2022.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
        Transport
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Lithuania" title="Transport in Lithuania">
        Transport in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania-roads-(E).png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="469" data-file-width="595" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/220px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/330px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png/440px-Lithuania-roads-%28E%29.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lithuania-roads-(E).png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Major highways in Lithuania
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="670" data-file-width="1005" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG/220px-Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG/330px-Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG/440px-Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nutiesti_pirmieji_Rail_baltica_b%C4%97giai.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Construction of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dual-gauge" title="Dual-gauge">
          dual-gauge
         </a>
         railway track in Lithuania (
         <a href="/wiki/Rail_Baltica" title="Rail Baltica">
          Rail Baltica
         </a>
         project)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania received its first railway connection in the middle of the 19th century, when the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warsaw_%E2%80%93_Saint_Petersburg_Railway" title="Warsaw – Saint Petersburg Railway">
        Warsaw – Saint Petersburg Railway
       </a>
       was constructed. It included a stretch from
       <a href="/wiki/Daugavpils" title="Daugavpils">
        Daugavpils
       </a>
       via Vilnius and Kaunas to Virbalis. The first and only still operating
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Railway_Tunnel" title="Kaunas Railway Tunnel">
        tunnel
       </a>
       was completed in 1860.
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Railways" title="Lithuanian Railways">
        Lithuanian Railways
       </a>
       ' main network consists of 1,762 km (1,095 mi) of 1,520 mm (4 ft 11.8 in)
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broad_gauge" title="Broad gauge">
        broad gauge
       </a>
       railway of which 122 km (76 mi) are electrified. Today, railway network consists of 115 km (71 mi) of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" title="Standard gauge">
        standard gauge
       </a>
       lines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than half of all inland freight transported in Lithuania is carried by rail.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Trans-European standard gauge
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_Baltica" title="Rail Baltica">
        Rail Baltica
       </a>
       railway, linking
       <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">
        Helsinki
       </a>
       –
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       –
       <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">
        Riga
       </a>
       –
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       –
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">
        Warsaw
       </a>
       and continuing on to Berlin is under construction. In 2017,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lietuvos_Gele%C5%BEinkeliai" title="Lietuvos Geležinkeliai">
        Lietuvos Geležinkeliai
       </a>
       , a company that operates most railway lines in Lithuania, received almost maximum possible EU penalty for breaching EU's antitrust laws and restricting competition.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Transportation is the 3rd largest sector in Lithuanian economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanian transport companies drew attention in 2016
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 2017
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with huge and record-breaking orders of trucks. Almost 90% of commercial truck traffic in Lithuania is international transports, the highest of any EU country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania has an extensive network of motorways. The best known motorways are
       <a href="/wiki/A1_highway_(Lithuania)" title="A1 highway (Lithuania)">
        A1
       </a>
       , connecting Vilnius, Kaunas and Klaipėda, as well as
       <a href="/wiki/A2_highway_(Lithuania)" title="A2 highway (Lithuania)">
        A2
       </a>
       , connecting Vilnius and
       <a href="/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys" title="Panevėžys">
        Panevėžys
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/European_route_E67" title="European route E67">
        European route E67
       </a>
       is a very busy highway running through Kaunas and connecting
       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">
        Warsaw
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Tallinn" title="Tallinn">
        Tallinn
       </a>
       . In 2017, Lithuanian roads were ranked 36th in the world with a negative future outlook – the road quality is expected to deteriorate.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An analysis revealed that roads are not sufficiently maintained
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and their condition is deteriorating compared to previous years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Road conditions are critical in several remote regions according to
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Linava&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Linava (page does not exist)">
        Linava
       </a>
       , a Lithuanian transport association.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Continuous deterioration is expected due to noticeable decreases in roadwork funding
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and planned decrease in EU's financial support.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Klaip%C4%97da" title="Port of Klaipėda">
        Port of Klaipėda
       </a>
       is the only commercial cargo port in Lithuania. In 2011 45.5 million tons of cargo were handled (including
       <a href="/wiki/B%C5%ABting%C4%97_oil_terminal" title="Būtingė oil terminal">
        Būtingė oil terminal
       </a>
       figures)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Klaip%C4%97da" title="Port of Klaipėda">
        Port of Klaipėda
       </a>
       is outside of EU's 20 largest ports,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but it is the 8th largest port in the Baltic Sea region
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with ongoing expansion plans.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_International_Airport" title="Vilnius International Airport">
        Vilnius International Airport
       </a>
       is the largest airport in Lithuania, but not among
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe" title="List of the busiest airports in Europe">
        EU's 100 largest airports
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It served 3.8 million passengers in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other international airports include
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Airport" title="Kaunas Airport">
        Kaunas International Airport
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Palanga_International_Airport" title="Palanga International Airport">
        Palanga International Airport
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai_International_Airport" title="Šiauliai International Airport">
        Šiauliai International Airport
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Airport" title="Kaunas Airport">
        Kaunas International Airport
       </a>
       is also a small commercial cargo airport which started regular commercial cargo traffic in 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">
        Energy
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Lithuania" title="Energy in Lithuania">
        Energy in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Ignalina_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant">
        Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant
       </a>
