       was a Soviet-era nuclear station. Unit No. 1 was closed in December 2004, as a condition of Lithuania's entry into the European Union; the plant is similar to the
       <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant">
        Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant
       </a>
       in its lack of a robust containment structure. The remaining unit, as of 2006
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , supplied about 70% of Lithuania's electrical demand.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Unit No. 2 was closed down on 31 December 2009. Proposals have been made to construct another –
       <a href="/wiki/Visaginas_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Visaginas Nuclear Power Plant">
        Visaginas Nuclear Power Plant
       </a>
       in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, a non-binding referendum held in October 2012 clouded the prospects for the Visaginas project, as 63% of voters said no to a new nuclear power plant.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The country's main primary source of electrical power is
       <a href="/wiki/Elektr%C4%97nai_Power_Plant" title="Elektrėnai Power Plant">
        Elektrėnai Power Plant
       </a>
       . Other primary sources of Lithuania's electrical power are
       <a href="/wiki/Kruonis_Pumped_Storage_Plant" title="Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant">
        Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_Hydroelectric_Power_Plant" title="Kaunas Hydroelectric Power Plant">
        Kaunas Hydroelectric Power Plant
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Kruonis_Pumped_Storage_Plant" title="Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant">
        Kruonis Pumped Storage Plant
       </a>
       is the only in the Baltic states power plant to be used for regulation of the power system's operation with generating capacity of 900 MW for at least 12 hours.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2015
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 66% of electrical power was imported.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Lithuania" title="Demographics of Lithuania">
        Demographics of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Lithuania.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="457" data-file-width="638" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Population_of_Lithuania.svg/300px-Population_of_Lithuania.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Population_of_Lithuania.svg/450px-Population_of_Lithuania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Population_of_Lithuania.svg/600px-Population_of_Lithuania.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Lithuania.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Population of Lithuania (in millions), 1950–2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="610" data-file-width="776" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/300px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/450px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg/600px-Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_municipalities_of_Lithuania_modified.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Population density
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Since the Neolithic period the native inhabitants of the Lithuanian territory have not been replaced by any other ethnic group, so there is a high probability that the inhabitants of present-day Lithuania have preserved the genetic composition of their forebears relatively undisturbed by the major demographic movements,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although without being actually isolated from them.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Lithuanian population appears to be relatively homogeneous, without apparent genetic differences among ethnic subgroups.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A 2004 analysis of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MtDNA" title="MtDNA">
        MtDNA
       </a>
       in the Lithuanian population revealed that Lithuanians are close to the
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_languages" title="Finno-Ugric languages">
        Finno-Ugric
       </a>
       speaking populations of Northern and Eastern Europe.
       <a href="/wiki/Y_chromosome" title="Y chromosome">
        Y-chromosome
       </a>
       SNP
       <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup" title="Haplogroup">
        haplogroup
       </a>
       analysis showed Lithuanians to be closest to
       <a href="/wiki/Latvians" title="Latvians">
        Latvians
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonians" title="Estonians">
        Estonians
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to 2014 estimates, the age structure of the population was as follows: 0–14 years, 13.5% (male 243,001/female 230,674); 15–64 years: 69.5% (male 1,200,196/female 1,235,300); 65 years and over: 16.8% (male 207,222/female 389,345).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The median age was 41.2 years (male: 38.5, female: 43.7).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania has a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility_rate" title="Sub-replacement fertility rate">
        sub-replacement fertility rate
       </a>
       : the
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       (TFR) in Lithuania is 1.59 children born/woman (2015 estimates).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2014
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 29% of births were to unmarried women.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_at_first_marriage" title="Age at first marriage">
        age at first marriage
       </a>
       in 2013 was 27 years for women and 29.3 years for men.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">
        Ethnic groups
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_Lithuania" title="Ethnic minorities in Lithuania">
        Ethnic minorities in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">
        <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:#ddd">
          <th colspan="5">
           Residents of Lithuania by ethnicity (2015)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-ethn_1-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-stat-ethn-1">
             [1]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Lithuanians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:green; width:86.7%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           86.7%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Poles
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:red; width:5.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           5.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Russians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:blue; width:4.8%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.8%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Belarusians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:purple; width:1.3%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           1.3%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Ukrainians
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:brown; width:0.7%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.7%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Others
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:gray; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Ethnic Lithuanians make up about five-sixths of the country's population and Lithuania has the most homogenous population in the Baltic States. In 2015, the population of Lithuania stands at 2,921,262, 86.7% of whom are ethnic
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_people" title="Lithuanian people">
        Lithuanians
       </a>
       who speak
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       , which is the official language of the country. Several sizable minorities exist, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">
        Poles
       </a>
       (5.6%),
       <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">
        Russians
       </a>
       (4.8%),
       <a href="/wiki/Belarusians" title="Belarusians">
        Belarusians
       </a>
       (1.3%) and
       <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">
        Ukrainians
       </a>
       (0.7%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-ethn_1-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat-ethn-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Poles_in_Lithuania" title="Poles in Lithuania">
        Poles in Lithuania
       </a>
       are the largest minority, concentrated in southeast Lithuania (the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_region" title="Vilnius region">
        Vilnius region
       </a>
       ).
       <a href="/wiki/Russians_in_Lithuania" title="Russians in Lithuania">
        Russians in Lithuania
       </a>
       are the second largest minority, concentrated mostly in two cities. They constitute sizeable minorities in
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       (12%)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaipėda">
        Klaipėda
       </a>
       (19.6%),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-osp.stat.gov.lt_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-osp.stat.gov.lt-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a majority in the town of
       <a href="/wiki/Visaginas" title="Visaginas">
        Visaginas
       </a>
       (52%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
        <a href="#cite_note-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 3,000
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Roma
       </a>
       live in Lithuania, mostly in Vilnius,
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       and Panevėžys; their organizations are supported by the National Minority and Emigration Department.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For centuries a small
       <a href="/wiki/Lipka_Tatars" title="Lipka Tatars">
        Tatar
       </a>
       community has flourished in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The former "
       <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">
        Solidarity
       </a>
       " leader and Polish President
       <a href="/wiki/Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa" title="Lech Wałęsa">
        Lech Wałęsa
       </a>
       criticized the government of Lithuania over
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanization" title="Lithuanization">
        discrimination
       </a>
       against the
       <a href="/wiki/Poles_in_Lithuania" title="Poles in Lithuania">
        Polish minority
       </a>
       , which included the enforced
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanization" title="Lithuanization">
        Lithuanization
       </a>
       of Polish
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surnames" title="Surnames">
        surnames
       </a>
       (e.g.
       <i>
        Liszkowska
       </i>
       to
       <i>
        Liškovska
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        Liškauskienė
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        Kleczkowski
       </i>
       to
       <i>
        Klečkovski
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        Klečkovskis
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
          <span title="The state's laws do not allow the writing of foreign letters (Polish in this instance) in the OFFICIAL documents of its citizens. (October 2017)">
           specify
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       and the removal of bilingual Polish language street signs in municipalities predominantly inhabited by the Polish speaking population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
          <span title="The state's laws do not allow foreign language (Polish in this instance) signs of streets, cities, towns, villages or any other subdivisions. (October 2017)">
           specify
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The official language is
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian
       </a>
       , other languages, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">
        Polish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">
        Russian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Belarusian_language" title="Belarusian language">
        Belarusian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">
        Ukrainian
       </a>
       , are spoken in the larger cities, and several municipalities such as
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0al%C4%8Dininkai_District_Municipality" title="Šalčininkai District Municipality">
        Šalčininkai District Municipality
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_District_Municipality" title="Vilnius District Municipality">
        Vilnius District Municipality
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Visaginas_Municipality" title="Visaginas Municipality">
        Visaginas Municipality
       </a>
       , but are not legally recognized by the Lithuanian government.
       <a href="/wiki/Yiddish" title="Yiddish">
        Yiddish
       </a>
       is spoken by members of the tiny remaining
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Lithuania" title="History of the Jews in Lithuania">
        Jewish community
       </a>
       in Lithuania. According to the Lithuanian population census of 2011,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-osp.stat.gov.lt_244-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-osp.stat.gov.lt-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       about 85% of the country's population speak Lithuanian as their native language, 7,2% are native speakers of Russian and 5,3% of Polish. According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       survey conducted in 2012, 80% of Lithuanians can speak Russian and 38% can speak English. Most Lithuanian schools teach English as the first foreign language, but students may also study German, or, in some schools, French or Russian. Schools where Russian or Polish are the primary languages of education exist in the areas populated by these minorities.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">
        Urbanization
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania" title="List of cities in Lithuania">
        List of cities in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       There has been a steady
       <a href="/wiki/Urbanization" title="Urbanization">
        movement of population to the cities
       </a>
       since the 1990s, encouraged by the planning of regional centres, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Alytus" title="Alytus">
        Alytus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marijampol%C4%97" title="Marijampolė">
        Marijampolė
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Utena" title="Utena">
        Utena
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Plung%C4%97" title="Plungė">
        Plungė
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ma%C5%BEeikiai" title="Mažeikiai">
        Mažeikiai
       </a>
       . By the early 21st century, about two-thirds of the total population lived in urban areas. As of 2015
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 66.5% of the total population lives in urban areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_238-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The largest city is
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       , followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da" title="Klaipėda">
        Klaipėda
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai" title="Šiauliai">
        Šiauliai
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys" title="Panevėžys">
        Panevėžys
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <table style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">
       <tr>
        <th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0.75em;">

         </div>

             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>

          <span style="font-size:110%;">
           Largest cities or towns in Lithuania
          </span>
          <br/>
          <span style="font-weight:normal;">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Statistics_Lithuania" title="Statistics Lithuania">
            Statistics Lithuania
           </a>
           (2015)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
            <a href="#cite_note-249">
             [249]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
        </th>
        <th>
         Rank
        </th>
        <th>
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania" title="List of cities in Lithuania">
          Name
         </a>
        </th>
        <th>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Functional_urban_areas">
        Functional urban areas
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zone" title="Larger urban zone">
        Functional urban areas
       </a>
       in Lithuania:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left;">
       <tr style="font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
        <th align="center">
         <a href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zone" title="Larger urban zone">
          Functional urban areas

        </th>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Lithuania" title="Health in Lithuania">
        Health in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       As of 2015
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanian
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       at birth was 73.4 (67.4 years for males and 78.8 for females)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
        <a href="#cite_note-251">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">
        infant mortality
       </a>
       rate was 6.2 per 1,000 births. The annual population growth rate increased by 0.3% in 2007. At 33.5 people per 100,000 in 2012, Lithuania has seen a dramatic rise in suicides in the post-Soviet years, and now records the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate" title="List of countries by suicide rate">
        fourth highest
       </a>
       age-standardized suicide rate in the world, according to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">
        WHO
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuania also has the highest
       <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">
        homicide
       </a>
       rate in the EU.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
        <a href="#cite_note-253">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Lithuania" title="Religion in Lithuania">
        Religion in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1155" data-file-width="3067" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/220px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/330px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg/440px-Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hill-of-crosses-siauliai.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hill_of_Crosses" title="Hill of Crosses">
          Hill of Crosses
         </a>
         near
         <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai" title="Šiauliai">
          Šiauliai
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       As per the 2011 census, 77.2% of Lithuanians belonged to the Roman Catholic Church.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-rel_254-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-stat-rel-254">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Church has been the majority denomination since the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianisation_of_Lithuania" title="Christianisation of Lithuania">
        Christianisation of Lithuania
       </a>
       at the end of the 14th century. The
       <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">
        Reformation
       </a>
       did not impact Lithuania to a great extent as seen in
       <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">
        Estonia
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       as generally only local Germans in the Klaipėda/Memel area turned Protestant, while Lithuanians and Poles remained Catholic, and Russians, Belarusians and Ukrainians—Eastern Orthodox. Some priests actively led the resistance against the Communist regime (symbolised by the
       <a href="/wiki/Hill_of_Crosses" title="Hill of Crosses">
        Hill of Crosses
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:300px; background: white;">
        <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:#ddd">
          <th colspan="5">
           Residents of Lithuania by religion (2011)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stat-rel_254-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-stat-rel-254">
             [254]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">
            Roman Catholic
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:green; width:77.2%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           77.2%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
            Orthodox
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:red; width:4.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Orthodox (
           <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">
            Old Believers
           </a>
           )
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:blue; width:0.8%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.8%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
            Lutheran
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:yellow; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">
            Reformed
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:brown; width:0.2%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.2%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Others
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:orange; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           No religion
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:purple; width:6.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           6.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           Did not specify
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:gray; width:10.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           10.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       4.1% are
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Eastern Orthodox
       </a>
       , mainly among the Russian minority. This group is distinguishable into the Eastern Orthodox Church and Old Believers.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">
        Protestants
       </a>
       are 0.8%, of which 0.6% are
       <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">
        Lutheran
       </a>
       and 0.2% are
       <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">
        Reformed
       </a>
       . According to Losch (1932), the Lutherans were 3.3% of the total population;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lmaleidykla.lt_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lmaleidykla.lt-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       they were mainly
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        Germans
       </a>
       in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memel_territory" title="Memel territory">
        Memel territory
       </a>
       (now Klaipėda). There was also a tiny Reformed community (0,5%),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lmaleidykla.lt_255-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-lmaleidykla.lt-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which still persists. Protestantism has declined with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flight_and_expulsion_of_Germans" title="Flight and expulsion of Germans">
        removal of the German population
       </a>
       , and today it is mainly represented by ethnic Lithuanians throughout the northern and western parts of the country, as well as in large urban areas. Believers and clergy suffered greatly during the Soviet occupation, with many killed, tortured or deported to Siberia. Newly arriving
       <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">
        evangelical churches
       </a>
       have established missions in Lithuania since 1990.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Tatars" title="Lithuanian Tatars">
        Lithuanian Tatars
       </a>
       maintained
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Lithuania" title="Islam in Lithuania">
        Islam
       </a>
       as their religion. 6.1% of Lithuanians have
       <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
        no religion
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania was historically home to a significant
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Lithuania" title="History of the Jews in Lithuania">
        Jewish community
       </a>
       and was an important center of Jewish scholarship and culture from the 18th century until the eve of World War II. Prior to the war, the Jewish population, outside of the Vilnius region (which was then in Poland), numbered about 160,000. In September 1939, tens of thousands of Polish Jews became Lithuanian subjects when the Soviets transferred the Vilnius region (of the former Polish state) to Lithuania and additional Jewish refugees arrived in Lithuania during the period prior to June 1941. Of the approximately 220,000 Jews who lived in the Republic of Lithuania in June 1941, almost all were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust_in_Lithuania" title="Holocaust in Lithuania">
        entirely annihilated
       </a>
       during
       <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">
        the Holocaust
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bubnys_vanished219_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bubnys_vanished219-257">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The community numbered about 4,000 at the end of 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stats_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Stats-259">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Romuva_(religion)" title="Romuva (religion)">
        Romuvan
       </a>
       religion has gained popularity over the years. It is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neopaganism" title="Neopaganism">
        contemporary continuation
       </a>
       of the traditional
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_religion" title="Ethnic religion">
        ethnic religion
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">
        Baltic peoples
       </a>
       , reviving the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_mythology" title="Lithuanian mythology">
        ancient religious practices
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanians" title="Lithuanians">
        Lithuanians
       </a>
       before
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Lithuania" title="Christianization of Lithuania">
        their Christianization
       </a>
       in 1387. Romuva claims to continue living
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_mythology" title="Baltic mythology">
        Baltic pagan
       </a>
       traditions, which survived in folklore and customs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
        <a href="#cite_note-261">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Romuva is a
       <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">
        polytheistic
       </a>
       pagan faith, which asserts the sanctity of nature and has elements of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancestor_worship" title="Ancestor worship">
        ancestor worship
       </a>
       . Practising the Romuva faith is seen by many adherents as a form of cultural pride, along with celebrating traditional forms of art, retelling Baltic folklore, practising traditional holidays, playing traditional Baltic music, singing traditional
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Daina_(Lithuania)" title="Daina (Lithuania)">
         dainas
        </a>
       </i>
       or hymns and songs as well as ecological activism and stewarding sacred places.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_census_of_2001" title="Lithuanian census of 2001">
        2001 census
       </a>
       , there were 1,270 people of Baltic faith in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
        <a href="#cite_note-264">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       That number jumped to 5,118 in the 2011 census.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Inija_Trink%C5%ABnien%C4%97&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Inija Trinkūnienė (page does not exist)">
        Inija Trinkūnienė
       </a>
       is the current Krivė (high priest) of the community since 2015, being the first known woman Krivė in the long pagan history.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">
        Oak
       </a>
       was considered as a divine tree, their groves were kept as sacred places with burning altars and were usually associated with the chief god
       <a href="/wiki/Perk%C5%ABnas" title="Perkūnas">
        Perkūnas
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thunder_god" title="Thunder god">
        thunder god
       </a>
       ) by Lithuanians in the ancient times.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Stelmu%C5%BE%C4%97_Oak" title="Stelmužė Oak">
        Stelmužė Oak
       </a>
       is the most significant oak, being at least 1,500 years old.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nowadays, Lithuanians are still planting oaks or other trees on special occasions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tilia" title="Tilia">
        Linden
       </a>
       of the then 16-year-old Olympic Champion
       <a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97" title="Rūta Meilutytė">
        Rūta Meilutytė
       </a>
       was planted in 2012, and is located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Laisv%C4%97s_al%C4%97ja" title="Laisvės alėja">
        Laisvės alėja
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
        <a href="#cite_note-270">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:1020px;max-width:1020px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romuva_sanctuary.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="968" data-file-width="1100" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/200px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/300px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Romuva_sanctuary.jpg/400px-Romuva_sanctuary.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">
          <a href="/wiki/Romuva_(temple)" title="Romuva (temple)">
           Romuva sanctuary
          </a>
          in
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sambia" title="Sambia">
           Sambia
          </a>
          , where Krivis, the chief priest or "pagan pope", lived and ruled over the religion of all the
          <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">
           Balts
          </a>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
           <a href="#cite_note-271">
            [271]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="6626" data-file-width="6884" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/200px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/300px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/400px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">
          <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Peter_and_St._Paul,_Vilnius" title="Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Vilnius">
           Church of St. Peter and St. Paul
          </a>
          in
          <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
           Vilnius
          </a>
          . Lithuania has strong Roman Catholic traditions.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1,_Kaunas,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="5000" data-file-width="4528" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/200px-Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/300px-Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/400px-Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery_interior_1%2C_Kaunas%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">
          Interior of the
          <a href="/wiki/Pa%C5%BEaislis_Monastery" title="Pažaislis Monastery">
           Pažaislis Monastery
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_(5990381200).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="665" data-file-width="907" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg/200px-Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg/300px-Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg/400px-Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Theotokos" title="Cathedral of the Theotokos">
           Cathedral of the Theotokos
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">
           Russian Orthodox Church
          </a>
          , which is one of the most ancient churches of Vilnius built in 1346.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg/200px-Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg/300px-Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg/400px-Synagogue_of_Vilnius.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:center">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choral_Synagogue_of_Vilnius" title="Choral Synagogue of Vilnius">
           Choral Synagogue of Vilnius
          </a>
          , the only synagogue in the city to survive
          <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Lithuania" title="The Holocaust in Lithuania">
           the Nazi Holocaust
          </a>
          . Almost whole rich culture of the
          <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Jews" title="Lithuanian Jews">
           Litvaks
          </a>
          was destroyed during the occupation.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to the most recent
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer Poll
       </a>
       in 2010,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUROBAROMETER_272-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EUROBAROMETER-272">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       47% of Lithuanian citizens responded that "they believe there is a God", 37% answered that "they believe there is some sort of
       <a href="/wiki/Spirit" title="Spirit">
        spirit
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_(spirituality)" title="Energy (spirituality)">
        life force
       </a>
       ", and 12% said that "they do not believe there is any sort of
       <a href="/wiki/Spirit" title="Spirit">
        spirit
       </a>
       , god, or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_(spirituality)" title="Energy (spirituality)">
        life force
       </a>
       ".
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Lithuania" title="Education in Lithuania">
        Education in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GreatCourtyard.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="763" data-file-width="592" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/170px-GreatCourtyard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/255px-GreatCourtyard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/GreatCourtyard.jpg/340px-GreatCourtyard.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GreatCourtyard.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">
          Vilnius University
         </a>
         , one of the oldest universities in Eastern and Central Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Modern Lithuanian education system has multiple structural problems. Insufficient funding and quality issues are the most prevalent. School attendance rates are above EU average and school leave is less common than EU average. However, PISA report from 2010 found that Lithuanian results in math, science and reading were below OECD average.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       PISA report from 2015 reconfirmed these findings.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuanian teacher salaries are lowest in entire EU.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
        <a href="#cite_note-275">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Low teacher salaries was the primary reason behind national teacher strikes in 2014,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
        <a href="#cite_note-276">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       2015,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
        <a href="#cite_note-279">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A strike was planned in 2017, but it did not materialise.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Instead, a protest was arranged at the end of 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lrt.lt_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lrt.lt-281">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Salaries in the higher education sector are also notoriously low. Many Lithuanian professors supplement their income by having a second job.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to parliamentarian
       <a href="/wiki/Mantas_Adom%C4%97nas" title="Mantas Adomėnas">
        Mantas Adomėnas
       </a>
       , problem with low salaries is well known, but education is not a politically prioritised matter in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lrt.lt_281-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-lrt.lt-281">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In an attempt to reduce costs
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and adapt to sharply decreasing number of high-school students
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , Lithuanian parliament decided to reduce the number of universities in Lithuania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In early 2018,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Sports_University" title="Lithuanian Sports University">
        Lithuanian Sports University
       </a>
       was merged into
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Health_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Health Sciences">
        Lithuanian University of Health Sciences
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive.org1_287-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-archive.org1-287">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Around the same time, two other universities –
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Educational_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences">
        Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aleksandras_Stulginskis_University" title="Aleksandras Stulginskis University">
        Aleksandras Stulginskis University
       </a>
       were merged into
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University" title="Vytautas Magnus University">
        Vytautas Magnus University
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
        <a href="#cite_note-288">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many Lithuanian academics,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as minister of education,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , students,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       researchers,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and university administrations
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       fought against the mergers.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_and_Science_of_the_Republic_of_Lithuania" title="Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Lithuania">
        Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Lithuania
       </a>
       proposes national educational policies and goals. These are sent to the Seimas for ratification. Laws govern long-term educational strategy along with general laws on standards for higher education, vocational training, law and science, adult education, and special education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu1_294-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-edu1-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       County administrators, municipal administrators, and school founders (including non-governmental organizations, religious organizations, and individuals) are responsible for implementing these policies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu1_294-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-edu1-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By constitutional mandate, ten years of formal enrollment in an educational institution is mandatory, ending at age 16.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="853" data-file-width="1280" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg/220px-Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg/330px-Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg/440px-Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Raudones_pilis_pavasari.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Raudon%C4%97" title="Raudonė">
          Raudonė
         </a>
         Basic School, located in
         <a href="/wiki/Raudon%C4%97_Castle" title="Raudonė Castle">
          Raudonė Castle
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       14.7% of the 2014 state budget was allocated to education expenses.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-smnedu_296-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-smnedu-296">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Primary and secondary schools receive funding from the state via their municipal or county administrations. The
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania" title="Constitution of Lithuania">
        Constitution of Lithuania
       </a>
       guarantees tuition-free attendance at public institutions of higher education for students deemed 'good'; the number of such students has varied over the past decade, with 53.5% exempted from tuition fees in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gseedu_297-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gseedu-297">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="761" data-file-width="1142" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG/220px-VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG/330px-VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG/440px-VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         One of the
         <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University_Library" title="Vilnius University Library">
          Vilnius University Library
         </a>
         reading rooms, decorated in 1803 with the portraits of the 12 most prominent figures in
         <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">
          antique
         </a>
         art and science
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       designates the literacy rate of Lithuanian persons aged 15 years and older as 100%
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and, according to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       Lithuania leads among other countries of
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        EU
       </a>
       by people with secondary education (93.3%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [299]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2012
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 34% of the population aged 25 to 64 had completed tertiary education; 59.1% had completed upper secondary and post-secondary (non-tertiary) education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As with other
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">
        Baltic
       </a>
       nations, in particular
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       , the large volume of higher education graduates within the country, coupled with the high rate of spoken second languages is contributing to an education
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">
        brain drain
       </a>
       . Many Lithuanians are choosing to emigrate seeking higher earning employment and studies throughout Europe. Since their inclusion into the European Union in 2004, Lithuania's population has fallen by approximately 180,000 people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
        <a href="#cite_note-301">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
        <a href="#cite_note-302">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2008
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lithuania&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there were 15 public universities in Lithuania, 6 private institutions, 16 public colleges, and 11 private colleges.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_University" title="Vilnius University">
        Vilnius University
       </a>
       is one of the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">
        oldest universities in Northern Europe
       </a>
       and the largest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Lithuania" title="List of universities in Lithuania">
        university in Lithuania
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas_University_of_Technology" title="Kaunas University of Technology">
        Kaunas University of Technology
       </a>
       is the largest technical university in the Baltic States and the 2nd largest university in Lithuania. Other universities include
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Health_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Health Sciences">
        Lithuanian University of Health Sciences
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Academy_of_Music_and_Theatre" title="Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre">
        Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Educational_Sciences" title="Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences">
        Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University" title="Vytautas Magnus University">
        Vytautas Magnus University
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mykolas_Romeris_University" title="Mykolas Romeris University">
        Mykolas Romeris University
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Academy_of_Physical_Education" title="Lithuanian Academy of Physical Education">
        Lithuanian Academy of Physical Education
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius_Gediminas_Technical_University" title="Vilnius Gediminas Technical University">
        Vilnius Gediminas Technical University
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Jonas_Zemaitis_Military_Academy_of_Lithuania" title="General Jonas Zemaitis Military Academy of Lithuania">
        The General Jonas Zemaitis Military Academy of Lithuania
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_University" title="Klaipėda University">
        Klaipėda University
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Veterinary_Academy" title="Lithuanian Veterinary Academy">
        Lithuanian Veterinary Academy
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Agriculture" title="Lithuanian University of Agriculture">
        Lithuanian University of Agriculture
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai_University" title="Šiauliai University">
        Šiauliai University
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vilnius_Academy_of_Art" title="Vilnius Academy of Art">
        Vilnius Academy of Art
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/LCC_International_University" title="LCC International University">
        LCC International University
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Lithuania" title="Culture of Lithuania">
        Culture of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lithuanian_language">
        Lithuanian language
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian language
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian language
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        lietuvių kalba
       </i>
       ) is the official state language of Lithuania and is recognized as one of the
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official languages
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       . There are about 2.96 million native Lithuanian speakers in Lithuania and about 0.2 million abroad.
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuanian is a
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">
        Baltic language
       </a>
       , closely related to
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">
        Latvian
       </a>
       , although they are not
       <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">
        mutually intelligible
       </a>
       . It is written in an adapted version of the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">
        Roman script
       </a>
       . Lithuanian is believed to be the
       <a href="/wiki/Conservative_(language)" title="Conservative (language)">
        linguistically most conservative
       </a>
       living
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
        Indo-European tongue
       </a>
       , retaining many features of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto_Indo-European_language" title="Proto Indo-European language">
        Proto Indo-European
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zinkevicius_304-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-zinkevicius-304">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_literature" title="Lithuanian literature">
        Lithuanian literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="682" data-file-width="508" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg/170px-Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg/255px-Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg/340px-Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mazvydo_katekizmas.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The first Lithuanian
         <a href="/wiki/Printing" title="Printing">
          printed
         </a>
         book
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas" title="Catechism of Martynas Mažvydas">
           Catechism of Martynas Mažvydas
          </a>
         </i>
         (1547, Königsberg)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There is a great deal of Lithuanian literature written in
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       , the main scholarly language of the Middle Ages. The edicts of the Lithuanian King
       <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas" title="Mindaugas">
        Mindaugas
       </a>
       is the prime example of the literature of this kind. The
       <a href="/wiki/Letters_of_Gediminas" title="Letters of Gediminas">
        Letters of Gediminas
       </a>
       are another crucial heritage of the Lithuanian Latin writings.
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuanian literary works in the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">
        Lithuanian language
       </a>
       started being first published in the 16th century. In 1547
       <a href="/wiki/Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas" title="Martynas Mažvydas">
        Martynas Mažvydas
       </a>
       compiled and published the first printed Lithuanian book
       <i>
        The Simple Words of Catechism
       </i>
       , which marks the beginning of printed Lithuanian literature. He was followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Dauk%C5%A1a" title="Mikalojus Daukša">
        Mikalojus Daukša
       </a>
       with
       <i>
        Katechizmas
       </i>
       . In the 16th and 17th centuries, as in the whole Christian Europe, Lithuanian literature was primarily religious.
      </p>
      <p>
       The evolution of the old (14th–18th century) Lithuanian literature ends with
       <a href="/wiki/Kristijonas_Donelaitis" title="Kristijonas Donelaitis">
        Kristijonas Donelaitis
       </a>
       , one of the most prominent authors of the
       <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">
        Age of Enlightenment
       </a>
       . Donelaitis' poem
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Seasons_(poem)" title="The Seasons (poem)">
         The Seasons
        </a>
       </i>
       is a landmark of the Lithuanian fiction literature.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INST_305-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-INST-305">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       With a mix of
       <a href="/wiki/Classicism" title="Classicism">
        Classicism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sentimentalism_(literature)" title="Sentimentalism (literature)">
        Sentimentalism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
        Romanticism
       </a>
       , the Lithuanian literature of the first half of the 19th century is represented by
       <a href="/wiki/Maironis" title="Maironis">
        Maironis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Baranauskas" title="Antanas Baranauskas">
        Antanas Baranauskas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Simonas_Daukantas" title="Simonas Daukantas">
        Simonas Daukantas
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Simonas_Stanevi%C4%8Dius" title="Simonas Stanevičius">
        Simonas Stanevičius
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INST_305-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-INST-305">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the Tsarist annexation of Lithuania in the 19th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_press_ban" title="Lithuanian press ban">
        Lithuanian press ban
       </a>
       was implemented, which led to the formation of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knygne%C5%A1iai" title="Knygnešiai">
        Knygnešiai
       </a>
       (Book smugglers) movement. This movement is thought to be the very reason the Lithuanian language and literature survived until today.
      </p>
      <p>
       20th-century Lithuanian literature is represented by
       <a href="/wiki/Juozas_Tumas-Vai%C5%BEgantas" title="Juozas Tumas-Vaižgantas">
        Juozas Tumas-Vaižgantas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Vienuolis" title="Antanas Vienuolis">
        Antanas Vienuolis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bernardas_Brazd%C5%BEionis" title="Bernardas Brazdžionis">
        Bernardas Brazdžionis
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Ma%C4%8Dernis" title="Vytautas Mačernis">
        Vytautas Mačernis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Justinas_Marcinkevi%C4%8Dius" title="Justinas Marcinkevičius">
        Justinas Marcinkevičius
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Arts_and_museums">
        Arts and museums
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Lithuania" title="List of museums in Lithuania">
        List of museums in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jonas_Mekas.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="533" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/170px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/255px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Jonas_Mekas.jpg/340px-Jonas_Mekas.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jonas_Mekas.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Mekas" title="Jonas Mekas">
          Jonas Mekas
         </a>
         is regarded as godfather of American
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avant-garde_cinema" title="Avant-garde cinema">
          avant-garde cinema
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Art_Museum" title="Lithuanian Art Museum">
        Lithuanian Art Museum
       </a>
       was founded in 1933 and is the largest museum of art conservation and display in Lithuania.
