       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Among other important museums is the
       <a href="/wiki/Palanga_Amber_Museum" title="Palanga Amber Museum">
        Palanga Amber Museum
       </a>
       , where
       <a href="/wiki/Amber" title="Amber">
        amber
       </a>
       pieces comprise a major part of the collection.
      </p>
      <p>
       Perhaps the most renowned figure in Lithuania's art community was the composer
       <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis">
        Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis
       </a>
       (1875–1911), an internationally renowned musician. The
       <a href="/wiki/2420_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="2420 Čiurlionis">
        2420 Čiurlionis
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Asteroid" title="Asteroid">
        asteroid
       </a>
       , identified in 1975, honors his achievements. The
       <a href="/wiki/M._K._%C4%8Ciurlionis_National_Art_Museum" title="M. K. Čiurlionis National Art Museum">
        M. K. Čiurlionis National Art Museum
       </a>
       , as well as the only military museum in Lithuania,
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great_War_Museum" title="Vytautas the Great War Museum">
        Vytautas the Great War Museum
       </a>
       , are located in Kaunas.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Lithuania" title="Music of Lithuania">
        Music of Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:672px;max-width:672px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg/220px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg/330px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg/440px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_10.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2733" data-file-width="3644" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg/220px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg/330px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg/440px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_11.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/220px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/330px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg/440px-Skamba_skamba_kankliai_2010_-_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:">
         Lithuanians with national clothes singing and dancing to the traditional songs in
         <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
          Vilnius
         </a>
         , Lithuania.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuanian folk music belongs to
       <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">
        Baltic
       </a>
       music branch which is connected with
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        neolithic
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corded_ware" title="Corded ware">
        corded ware
       </a>
       culture. Two instrument cultures meet in the areas inhabited by Lithuanians: stringed (
       <a href="/wiki/Kantele" title="Kantele">
        kanklių
       </a>
       ) and wind instrument cultures. Lithuanian folk music is archaic, mostly used for ritual purposes, containing elements of
       <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">
        paganism
       </a>
       faith. There are three ancient styles of singing in Lithuania connected with ethnographical regions:
       <a href="/wiki/Monophony" title="Monophony">
        monophony
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Heterophony" title="Heterophony">
        heterophony
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">
        polyphony
       </a>
       . Folk song genres: Sutartinės, Wedding Songs, War-Historical Time Songs, Calendar Cycle and Ritual Songs and Work Songs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis" title="Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis">
        Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis
       </a>
       is the most renowned Lithuanian painter and composer. During his short life he created about 200 pieces of music. His works have had profound influence on modern Lithuanian culture. His
       <a href="/wiki/Symphonic_poem" title="Symphonic poem">
        symphonic poems
       </a>
       <i>
        In the Forest
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        Miške
       </i>
       ) and
       <i>
        The Sea
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        Jūra
       </i>
       ) were performed only
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Posthumous_work" title="Posthumous work">
        posthumously
       </a>
       . Čiurlionis contributed to symbolism and art nouveau and was representative of the fin de siècle epoch. He has been considered one of the pioneers of abstract art in Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
        <a href="#cite_note-308">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:338px;max-width:338px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:112px;max-width:112px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_(2).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3504" data-file-width="2336" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg/110px-Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg/165px-Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg/220px-Vytauto_Kernagio_skulpt%C5%ABra_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="110"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antis_(2008-09-07)4.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2756" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/220px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/330px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg/440px-Antis_%282008-09-07%294.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left/right/center;background-color:">
         Under a firm
         <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Censorship in the Soviet Union">
          censorship
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Kernagis" title="Vytautas Kernagis">
          Vytautas Kernagis
         </a>
         and band
         <a href="/wiki/Antis" title="Antis">
          Antis
         </a>
         with its main vocalist
         <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Kau%C5%A1p%C4%97das" title="Algirdas Kaušpėdas">
          Algirdas Kaušpėdas
         </a>
         actively mocked the
         <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
          Soviet Union
         </a>
         regime by using
         <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">
          metaphors
         </a>
         in their lyrics.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1944)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1944)">
        Soviet reoccupation of Lithuania in 1944
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Censorship in the Soviet Union">
        Soviet's censorship
       </a>
       continued firmly controlling all artistic expressions in Lithuania, and any violations by criticizing the regime would immediately result in punishments.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
        <a href="#cite_note-309">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Unable to express their opinions directly, the Lithuanian artists began organizing patriotic
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roko_Mar%C5%A1as" title="Roko Maršas">
        Roko Maršai
       </a>
       and were using
       <a href="/wiki/Metaphor" title="Metaphor">
        metaphors
       </a>
       in their songs lyrics, which were easily identified for their true meanings by the locals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
        <a href="#cite_note-310">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
        <a href="#cite_note-311">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Postmodernist" title="Postmodernist">
        Postmodernist
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">
        rock
       </a>
       band
       <a href="/wiki/Antis" title="Antis">
        Antis
       </a>
       and its vocalist
       <a href="/wiki/Algirdas_Kau%C5%A1p%C4%97das" title="Algirdas Kaušpėdas">
        Algirdas Kaušpėdas
       </a>
       were one of the most active performers who mocked the Soviet regime by using metaphors. For example, in the song
       <i>
        Zombiai
       </i>
       (Zombies), the band indirectly sang about the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">
        Red Army
       </a>
       soldiers who occupied the state and its military base in
       <a href="/wiki/Ukmerg%C4%97" title="Ukmergė">
        Ukmergė
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
        <a href="#cite_note-312">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
        <a href="#cite_note-313">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Kernagis" title="Vytautas Kernagis">
        Vytautas Kernagis
       </a>
       ' song
       <i>
        Kolorado vabalai
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Colorado_potato_beetle" title="Colorado potato beetle">
        Colorado beetles
       </a>
       ) was also a favorite due to its lyrics in which true meaning of the Colorado beetles was intended to be the Soviets decorated with the
       <a href="/wiki/Ribbon_of_Saint_George" title="Ribbon of Saint George">
        Ribbons of Saint George
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1698" data-file-width="2534" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/220px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/330px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/440px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Song_Festival" title="Lithuanian Song Festival">
          Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Vytautas_Mi%C5%A1kinis" title="Vytautas Miškinis">
        Vytautas Miškinis
       </a>
       (born 1954) is a professor, composer and choir director of the famous Lithuanian boys' choir
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%84%C5%BEuoliukas" title="Ąžuoliukas">
        Ąžuoliukas
       </a>
       . He is very popular in Lithuania and abroad.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
        <a href="#cite_note-315">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Miškinis has written over 400 secular and about 160 religious works.
      </p>
      <p>
       In Lithuania,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choral_music" title="Choral music">
        choral music
       </a>
       is very important.
       <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">
        Vilnius
       </a>
       is the only city with three choirs laureates (Brevis, Jauna Muzika and Chamber Choir of the Conservatoire) at the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Grand_Prix_for_Choral_Singing" title="European Grand Prix for Choral Singing">
        European Grand Prix for Choral Singing
       </a>
       . There is a long-standing tradition of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Song_Festival" title="Lithuanian Song Festival">
        Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival
       </a>
       (Dainų šventė). The first one took place in
       <a href="/wiki/Kaunas" title="Kaunas">
        Kaunas
       </a>
       in 1924. Since 1990, the festival has been organised every four years and summons roughly 30,000 singers and folk dancers of various professional levels and age groups from across the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
        <a href="#cite_note-316">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2008, Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival together with its
       <a href="/wiki/Latvian_Song_and_Dance_Festival" title="Latvian Song and Dance Festival">
        Latvian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival" title="Estonian Song Festival">
        Estonian
       </a>
       versions was inscribed as
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">
        Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
        <a href="#cite_note-317">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the early independence years, rock band
       <a href="/wiki/Foje" title="Foje">
        Foje
       </a>
       was particularly popular and gathered tens of thousands of spectators to the concerts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After disbanding in 1997, Foje vocalist
       <a href="/wiki/Andrius_Mamontovas" title="Andrius Mamontovas">
        Andrius Mamontovas
       </a>
       remained one of the most prominent Lithuanian performers and an active participant in various
       <a href="/wiki/Charity_(practice)" title="Charity (practice)">
        charity
       </a>
       events.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Marijonas_Mikutavi%C4%8Dius" title="Marijonas Mikutavičius">
        Marijonas Mikutavičius
       </a>
       is famous for creating unofficial Lithuania sport anthem
       <i>
        Trys milijonai
       </i>
       (Three million) and official anthem of the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2011" title="EuroBasket 2011">
        EuroBasket 2011
       </a>
       <i>
        Nebetyli sirgaliai
       </i>
       (English version was named
       <i>
        Celebrate Basketball
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
        <a href="#cite_note-320">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_cuisine" title="Lithuanian cuisine">
        Lithuanian cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG/220px-Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG/330px-Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG/440px-Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cepelinai_Sauce.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Cepelinai" title="Cepelinai">
           Cepelinai
          </a>
         </i>
         , a
         <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">
          potato
         </a>
         -based dumpling dish characteristic of
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_cuisine" title="Lithuanian cuisine">
          Lithuanian cuisine
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuanian cuisine features the products suited to the cool and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">
        moist
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">
        northern climate
       </a>
       of Lithuania:
       <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">
        barley
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">
        potatoes
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">
        rye
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beet" title="Beet">
        beets
       </a>
       , greens, berries, and
       <a href="/wiki/Mushroom" title="Mushroom">
        mushrooms
       </a>
       are locally grown, and dairy products are one of its specialties. Since it shares its climate and agricultural practices with Northern Europe, Lithuanian cuisine has some similarities to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scandinavian_cuisine" title="Scandinavian cuisine">
        Scandinavian cuisine
       </a>
       . Nevertheless, it has its own distinguishing features, which were formed by a variety of influences during the country's long and difficult history.
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of their common heritage, Lithuanians, Poles, and
       <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">
        Ashkenazi Jews
       </a>
       share many dishes and beverages. Namely, similar versions of: dumplings (koldūnai, kreplach or
       <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">
        pierogi
       </a>
       ), doughnuts spurgos or (pączki), and blynai crêpes (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blintzes" title="Blintzes">
        blintzes
       </a>
       ).
       <a href="/wiki/German_cuisine" title="German cuisine">
        German traditions
       </a>
       also influenced Lithuanian cuisine, introducing pork and potato dishes, such as potato pudding (kugelis or kugel) and potato sausages (vėdarai), as well as the baroque tree cake known as
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0akotis" title="Šakotis">
        Šakotis
       </a>
       . The most exotic of all the influences is Eastern (Karaite) cuisine, and the dishes kibinai and čeburekai are popular in Lithuania. Torte Napoleon was introduced during
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">
        Napoleon
       </a>
       's passage through Lithuania in the 19th century.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Lithuania" title="Sport in Lithuania">
        Sport in Lithuania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3214" data-file-width="4478" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_de_Lituania_celebra_su_tercer_puesto_en_el_Mundial_de_baloncesto_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Lithuania men's national basketball team">
          Lithuania men's national basketball team
         </a>
         is ranked 5th worldwide in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_Rankings" title="FIBA Rankings">
          FIBA Rankings
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="580" data-file-width="382" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/170px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/255px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg/340px-R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97_portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97" title="Rūta Meilutytė">
          Rūta Meilutytė
         </a>
         –
         <a href="/wiki/Swimming_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Swimming at the Summer Olympics">
          Olympic
         </a>
         , multiple
         <a href="/wiki/FINA_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="FINA World Aquatics Championships">
          World
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/European_Short_Course_Swimming_Championships" title="European Short Course Swimming Championships">
          European
         </a>
         champion.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Basketball is the most popular and
       <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">
        national sport
       </a>
       of Lithuania. The
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Lithuania men's national basketball team">
        Lithuania national basketball team
       </a>
       has had significant success in international basketball events, having won the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket" title="EuroBasket">
        EuroBasket
       </a>
       on three occasions (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1937" title="Eurobasket 1937">
        1937
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1939" title="Eurobasket 1939">
        1939
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_2003" title="Eurobasket 2003">
        2003
       </a>
       ), as well a total of 8 other medals in the Eurobasket, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Championship" title="FIBA World Championship">
        World Championships
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the Summer Olympics">
        Olympic Games
       </a>
       . The men's national team also has extremely high TV ratings as about 76% of the country's population watched their games live in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Lithuania hosted the Eurobasket in 1939 and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eurobasket_2011" title="Eurobasket 2011">
        2011
       </a>
       . The historic Lithuanian basketball team
       <a href="/wiki/BC_%C5%BDalgiris" title="BC Žalgiris">
        BC Žalgiris
       </a>
       , from Kaunas, won the European basketball league
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euroleague" title="Euroleague">
        Euroleague
       </a>
       in 1999. Lithuania has produced a number of
       <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">
        NBA
       </a>
       players, including
       <a href="/wiki/Naismith_Memorial_Basketball_Hall_of_Fame" title="Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame">
        Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame
       </a>
       inductees
       <a href="/wiki/Arvydas_Sabonis" title="Arvydas Sabonis">
        Arvydas Sabonis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ar%C5%ABnas_Mar%C4%8Diulionis" title="Šarūnas Marčiulionis">
        Šarūnas Marčiulionis
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
        <a href="#cite_note-323">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and current NBA players
       <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Valan%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas" title="Jonas Valančiūnas">
        Jonas Valančiūnas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Domantas_Sabonis" title="Domantas Sabonis">
        Domantas Sabonis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mindaugas_Kuzminskas" title="Mindaugas Kuzminskas">
        Mindaugas Kuzminskas
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lithuania has won a total of
       <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_at_the_Olympics" title="Lithuania at the Olympics">
        25 medals at the Olympic Games
       </a>
       , including 6 gold medals in
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">
        athletics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Modern_pentathlon" title="Modern pentathlon">
        modern pentathlon
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shooting_sport" title="Shooting sport">
        shooting
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">
        swimming
       </a>
       . Numerous other Lithuanians won Olympic medals representing Soviet Union.
       <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw" title="Discus throw">
        Discus thrower
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Virgilijus_Alekna" title="Virgilijus Alekna">
        Virgilijus Alekna
       </a>
       is the most successful Olympic athlete of independent Lithuania, having won gold medals in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2000_Sydney_Olympics" title="2000 Sydney Olympics">
        2000 Sydney
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2004_Athens" title="2004 Athens">
        2004 Athens
       </a>
       games, as well as a bronze in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Beijing" title="2008 Beijing">
        2008 Beijing
       </a>
       Olympics and numerous
       <a href="/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="IAAF World Championships in Athletics">
        World Championship
       </a>
       medals. More recently, the gold medal won by a then 15-year-old swimmer
       <a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABta_Meilutyt%C4%97" title="Rūta Meilutytė">
        Rūta Meilutytė
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">
        2012 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in London sparked a rise in popularity for the sport in Lithuania.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Snow_Arena.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2248" data-file-width="4000" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/220px-Snow_Arena.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/330px-Snow_Arena.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Snow_Arena.JPG/440px-Snow_Arena.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Snow_Arena.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Druskininkai
         <a href="/wiki/Snow_Arena" title="Snow Arena">
          Snow Arena
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Lithuania has produced prominent athletes in athletics, modern pentathlon,
       <a href="/wiki/Road_cycling" title="Road cycling">
        road
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Track_cycling" title="Track cycling">
        track cycling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">
        chess
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rowing" title="Rowing">
        rowing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aerobatics" title="Aerobatics">
        aerobatics
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Strongest_Man" title="World's Strongest Man">
        strongman
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">
        wrestling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        boxing
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">
        mixed martial arts
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kyokushin" title="Kyokushin">
        Kyokushin Karate
       </a>
       and other sports.
      </p>
      <p>
       Few Lithuanian athletes have found success in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Winter_Sport" title="Winter Sport">
        winter sports
       </a>
       , although facilities are provided by several ice rinks and skiing slopes, including
       <a href="/wiki/Snow_Arena" title="Snow Arena">
        Snow Arena
       </a>
       , the first indoor ski slope in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltics" title="Baltics">
        Baltics
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_NoteA">
        <b>
         <a href="#ref_NoteA">
          ^
         </a>
        </b>
       </span>
       <small>
        Various sources classify Lithuania differently for statistical and other purposes. For example, United Nations
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_330-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-UN-330">
          [330]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Eurovoc" title="Eurovoc">
         Eurovoc
        </a>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
         <a href="#cite_note-331">
          [331]
         </a>
        </sup>
        among others, classify it as northern Europe, the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">
         CIA World Factbook
        </a>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_238-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-CIA-238">
          [238]
         </a>
        </sup>
        classifies it as eastern Europe, and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_Britannica" title="Encyclopedia Britannica">
         Encyclopedia Britannica
        </a>
        locates it in northeastern Europe.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
         <a href="#cite_note-332">
          [332]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Usage varies greatly, and controversially,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
         <a href="#cite_note-333">
          [333]
         </a>
        </sup>
        in press sources.
       </small>
      </p>

          </span>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Lietuvos+gyventoj%C5%B3+tautin%C4%97+sud%C4%97tis+2014%E2%80%932015+m.&amp;rft.pub=Alkas.lt&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Falkas.lt%2F2015%2F12%2F16%2Fa-butkus-lietuvos-gyventojai-tautybes-poziuriu%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">

            <sup>

              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>

           <a href="#cite_ref-Lina_2-1">

              </b>

          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Kulikauskienė, Lina (2002).
            <i>
             Lietuvos Respublikos Konstitucija
            </i>
            [
            <i>
             The Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania
            </i>
            ] (in Lithuanian). Native History, CD.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9986-9216-7-8" title="Special:BookSources/9986-9216-7-8">
             9986-9216-7-8
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Lietuvos+Respublikos+Konstitucija&amp;rft.pub=Native+History%2C+CD.&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=9986-9216-7-8&amp;rft.aulast=Kulikauskien%C4%97&amp;rft.aufirst=Lina&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-3">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-3">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            Veser, Ernst (23 September 1997).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.rchss.sinica.edu.tw/publication/ebook/journal/11-01-1999/11_1_2.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             "Semi-Presidentialism-Duverger's Concept — A New Political System Model"
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            (in English and Chinese). Department of Education, School of Education,
            <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cologne" title="University of Cologne">
             University of Cologne
            </a>
            : 39–60
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              23 August
             </span>
             2017
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Duhamel has developed the approach further: He stresses that the French construction does not correspond to either parliamentary or the presidential form of government, and then develops the distinction of 'système politique' and 'régime constitutionnel'. While the former comprises the exercise of power that results from the dominant institutional practice, the latter is the totality of the rules for the dominant institutional practice of the power. In this way, France appears as 'presidentialist system' endowed with a 'semi-presidential regime' (1983: 587). By this standard he recognizes Duverger's
             <i>
              pléiade
             </i>
             as semi-presidential regimes, as well as Poland, Romania, Bulgaria and Lithuania (1993: 87).
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidentialism-Duverger%27s+Concept+%E2%80%94+A+New+Political+System+Model&amp;rft.pages=39-60&amp;rft.date=1997-09-23&amp;rft.aulast=Veser&amp;rft.aufirst=Ernst&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rchss.sinica.edu.tw%2Fpublication%2Febook%2Fjournal%2F11-01-1999%2F11_1_2.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Draft-4">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Draft_4-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFShugart2005">
            <a href="/wiki/Matthew_S%C3%B8berg_Shugart" title="Matthew Søberg Shugart">
             Shugart, Matthew Søberg
            </a>
            (September 2005).
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080819200307/http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             "Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive and Mixed Authority Patterns"
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            .
            <i>
             Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies
            </i>
            . United States: University of California, San Diego. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            on 19 August 2008
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              23 August
             </span>
             2017
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Graduate+School+of+International+Relations+and+Pacific+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidential+Systems%3A+Dual+Executive+and+Mixed+Authority+Patterns&amp;rft.date=2005-09&amp;rft.aulast=Shugart&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew+S%C3%B8berg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdss.ucsd.edu%2F~mshugart%2Fsemi-presidentialism.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Dual-5">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Dual_5-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFShugart2005">
            <a href="/wiki/Matthew_S%C3%B8berg_Shugart" title="Matthew Søberg Shugart">
             Shugart, Matthew Søberg
            </a>
            (December 2005).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.palgrave-journals.com/fp/journal/v3/n3/pdf/8200087a.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             "Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive And Mixed Authority Patterns"
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            .
            <i>
             French Politics
            </i>
            .
            <a href="/wiki/Palgrave_Macmillan" title="Palgrave Macmillan">
             Palgrave Macmillan
            </a>
            Journals.
            <b>
             3
            </b>
            (3): 323–351.
            <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
             doi
            </a>
            :
            <span class="plainlinks">
             <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1057%2Fpalgrave.fp.8200087" rel="nofollow">
              10.1057/palgrave.fp.8200087
             </a>
             <img alt="Freely accessible" data-file-height="813" data-file-width="512" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/9px-Lock-green.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/14px-Lock-green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/18px-Lock-green.svg.png 2x" title="Freely accessible" width="9"/>
            </span>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              23 August
             </span>
             2017
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             A pattern similar to the French case of compatible majorities alternating with periods of cohabitation emerged in Lithuania, where Talat-Kelpsa (2001) notes that the ability of the Lithuanian president to influence government formation and policy declined abruptly when he lost the sympathetic majority in parliament.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=French+Politics&amp;rft.atitle=Semi-Presidential+Systems%3A+Dual+Executive+And+Mixed+Authority+Patterns&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=323-351&amp;rft.date=2005-12&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1057%2Fpalgrave.fp.8200087&amp;rft.aulast=Shugart&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew+S%C3%B8berg&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.palgrave-journals.com%2Ffp%2Fjournal%2Fv3%2Fn3%2Fpdf%2F8200087a.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

            </a>

         <li id="cite_note-14">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-14">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.eracon.info/?page=general-information" rel="nofollow">
            Lithuania – General Information
           </a>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ERASMUS_programme" title="ERASMUS programme">
            ERASMUS programme
           </a>
           Conference 2007.
           <i>
            "The name of Lithuania (Lietuva in Lithuanian) comes from the word "lietus" (rain)."
           </i>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-15">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-15">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a class="external text" href="http://search.delfi.lt/cache.php?id=410949EA3A0BC279" rel="nofollow">
            The Origin of the Name of Lithuania
           </a>
           . Zigmas Zinkevicius,
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Delfi.lt" title="Delfi.lt">
            Delfi.lt
           </a>
           , 1999.
           <i>
            "After the ineffectual efforts to find the name of Lithuania in foreign countries, it was finally associated to the Lithuanian word lietus ‘rain’, as though Lithuania were an extremely rainy land."
           </i>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Zigmas2-16">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.voruta.lt&amp;rft.atitle=Lietuvos+vardo+kilm%C4%97&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.voruta.lt%2Flietuvos-vardo-kilme%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Zigmas-19">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Zigmas_19-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Zigmas_19-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            Zinkevičius, Zigmas (1999-11-30).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.voruta.lt/archyvas/74/253" rel="nofollow">
             "Lietuvos vardo kilmė"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Voruta
            </i>

            (669).

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Lithuania%3A+Stepping+Westward&amp;rft.pages=ix%2C+xxi&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=0-415-26731-5&amp;rft.au=Thomas+Lane&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DfecMC0LXU-sC%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=LRS.lt&amp;rft.atitle=1791+m.+gegu%C5%BE%C4%97s+3+d.+Konstitucija&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww3.lrs.lt%2Fpdf%2FKonstitucija_1791.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-43">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-43">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://pmc.usc.edu/3May1791Constitution.htm" rel="nofollow">
             "History of the 3 May 1791 Constitution"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             pmc.usc.edu
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              22 December
             </span>
             2017
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=pmc.usc.edu&amp;rft.atitle=History+of+the+3+May+1791+Constitution&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpmc.usc.edu%2F3May1791Constitution.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-44">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-44">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           The claims of "first" and "second constitution" have been disputed, particularly as different scholars define the word constitution differently. Both the U.S. and Polish-Lithuanian constitutions were preceded by earlier ones, mainly non-governmental constitutions or statutory acts, which did not introduce the clear division of the executive, legislative and judiciary powers (considered during the Enlightenment by thinkers such as
           <a href="/wiki/Montesquieu" title="Montesquieu">
            Montesquieu
           </a>
           ), including some also termed constitutions. According to Koenigsberger, the
           <a href="/wiki/Corsican_Constitution" title="Corsican Constitution">
            Corsican Constitution
           </a>
           of 1755 did not separate the executive from the judiciary power. See
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_constitution" title="History of the constitution">
            history of the constitution
           </a>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-45">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-45">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110512014106/http://www.liw.lt/archive_vid.php?shid=1211283347&amp;id=1211283055" rel="nofollow">
             "The Roads to Independence"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Lithuania in the World
            </i>
            .
            <b>
             16
            </b>
            (2). 2008.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">
             ISSN
            </a>
            <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1392-0901" rel="nofollow">
             1392-0901
            </a>
            . Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.liw.lt/archive_vid.php?shid=1211283347&amp;id=1211283055" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 12 May 2011.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Lithuania+in+the+World&amp;rft.atitle=The+Roads+to+Independence&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.issn=1392-0901&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.liw.lt%2Farchive_vid.php%3Fshid%3D1211283347%26id%3D1211283055&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">

         </li>

           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-123">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation journal">
            G. Sakalauskiene and G. Ignatavicius (2003). "Research Note Effect of drought and fires on the quality of water in Lithuanian rivers".
            <i>
             Hydrology and Earth System Sciences
            </i>
            .
            <b>
             7
            </b>
            (3): 423–427.
            <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">
             Bibcode

            :
            <a class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003HESS....7..423S" rel="nofollow">

            .

             doi

            :
            <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.5194%2Fhess-7-423-2003" rel="nofollow">

            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hydrology+and+Earth+System+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=Research+Note+Effect+of+drought+and+fires+on+the+quality+of+water+in+Lithuanian+rivers&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=423-427&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.5194%2Fhess-7-423-2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2003HESS....7..423S&amp;rft.au=G.+Sakalauskiene+and+G.+Ignatavicius&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

         <li id="cite_note-archive.org-173">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-archive.org_173-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-archive.org_173-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>

            <a class="external text" href="http://events.le.lt/uploads/File/20060126/Electricity%20markets%20in%20BalticStates_Jank.ppt" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 3 March 2009
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              19 April
             </span>
             2008
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Electricity+Market+in+the+Baltic+Countries&amp;rft.pub=Lietuvos+Energija&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fevents.le.lt%2Fuploads%2FFile%2F20060126%2FElectricity%2520markets%2520in%2520BalticStates_Jank.ppt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">

          <span class="reference-text">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Ef.com&amp;rft.atitle=EF+English+Proficiency+Index+%E2%80%93+A+comprehensive+ranking+of+countries+by+English+skills&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ef.com%2Fca%2Fepi&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ALithuania">

        <a class="external text" href="http://www.ngw.nl/heraldrywiki/index.php?title=Lithuania" rel="nofollow">
         Heraldry
        </a>
        of Lithuania
       </li>
      </ul>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Travel
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.tourism.lt/en" rel="nofollow">
         Lithuanian State Department of Tourism
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110517005924/http://uzlietuva.lt/video/NXBB48O5XWAM/Essential-Lithuania-2010" rel="nofollow">
         Travel Channel movie about Lithuanian – "Essential Lithuania 2010"
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.travel.lt/index.php?lang=2" rel="nofollow">

       </li>

              </ul>
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>

                </ul>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
               <div>
                <div class="plainlist">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    1
                   </sup>
                   <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                    Oceanic islands
                   </a>
                   within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    2
                   </sup>
                   Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>

              <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
               History
              </th>
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

                     Timeline

                    </a>

                     by the Soviet Union (1940)
                    </a>
                   </li>

                    </a>
                   </li>

                    </a>

                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Deportations
                  <ul>
                   <li>

                    </a>
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states_under_Soviet_rule_(1944%E2%80%9391)" title="Baltic states under Soviet rule (1944–91)">
                   Under Soviet rule (1944-91)
                  </a>
                  <ul>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_war_in_the_Baltic_states" title="Guerrilla war in the Baltic states">
                     Guerrilla war
                    </a>
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      <a href="/wiki/Forest_Brothers" title="Forest Brothers">
                       Forest Brothers
                      </a>
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Sovietization_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Sovietization of the Baltic states">
                     Sovietization
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Singing_Revolution" title="Singing Revolution">
                     Singing Revolution
                    </a>
                   </li>
                   <li>
                    <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Way" title="Baltic Way">
                     Baltic Way
                    </a>
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
              <td class="navbox-image" rowspan="5" style="width:1px;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px">
               <div>
                <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baltic_states_flag_map.svg">

                 <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="810" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/23px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/35px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Flag_of_Europe.svg/46px-Flag_of_Europe.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                </span>
                <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
                 <span style="color:white;">
                  Council of Europe
                 </span>
                </a>
               </div>
              </th>

                  <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_2005" title="World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 2005">
                   6th (2005)
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_2009" title="World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 2009">
                   7th (2009)
                  </a>

                   8th (2011)
                  </a>

                   10th (2015)
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
               <div>
                <ol>
                 <li>
                  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China">
                   Special administrative regions of the People's Republic of China
                  </a>
                  , participates as "Hong Kong, China" and "Macao China".
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Officially the Republic of China, participates as "
                  <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">
                   Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu
                  </a>
                  ", and "Chinese Taipei" in short.
                 </li>
                </ol>

                <tr>
                 <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="padding-top:0;font-size:90%;line-height:1.0em;padding-bottom:0.4em;">
                  <div>
                   <span style="position: relative; top: 0.2em;">
                    <sup>
                     <small>
                      1
                     </small>
                    </sup>
                   </span>
                   Associate member.
                   <br/>
                   <span style="position: relative; top: 0.2em;">
                    <sup>
                     <small>
                      2
                     </small>
                    </sup>
                   </span>
                   Provisionally referred to by the Francophonie as the "former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia"; see
                   <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_naming_dispute" title="Macedonia naming dispute">
                    Macedonia naming dispute
                   </a>
                   .
